class="mw-body-content">\n\t\t\t\t<div id="siteSub" class="noprint">From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia</div>\t\t\t\t<div id="contentSub"><span class="mw-redirectedfrom">\xc2\xa0\xc2\xa0(Redirected from <a href="/w/index.php?title=First_World_War&amp;redirect=no" class="mw-redirect" title="First World War">First World War</a>)</span></div>\n\t\t\t\t<div id="jump-to-nav"></div>\t\t\t\t<a class="mw-jump-link" href="#mw-head">Jump to navigation</a>\n\t\t\t\t<a class="mw-jump-link" href="#p-search">Jump to search</a>\n\t\t\t\t<div id="mw-content-text" lang="en" dir="ltr" class="mw-content-ltr"><div class="mw-parser-output"><p class="mw-empty-elt">\n</p>\n<div class="shortdescription nomobile noexcerpt noprint searchaux" style="display:none">1914\xe2\x80\x931918 global war originating in Europe</div>\n<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">"World War One", "Great War", and "WW1" redirect here. For other uses, see <a href="/wiki/World_War_One_(disambiguation)" class="mw-disambig" title="World War One (disambiguation)">World War One (disambiguation)</a>, <a href="/wiki/Great_War_(disambiguation)" class="mw-disambig" title="Great War (disambiguation)">Great War (disambiguation)</a>, and <a href="/wiki/WW1_(album)" title="WW1 (album)">WW1 (album)</a>.</div>\n<p class="mw-empty-elt">\n\n</p>\n<div class="mw-stack mobile-float-reset" style="box-sizing:border-box;float:right;clear:right"><div style="overflow:hidden;margin:1px"><table class="infobox vevent" style="width:25.5em;border-spacing:2px;"><tbody><tr><th class="summary" colspan="2" style="background-color:#C3D6EF;text-align:center;vertical-align:middle;font-size:110%;">World War I</th></tr><tr><td colspan="2" style="text-align:center;border-bottom:1px solid #aaa;line-height:1.5em;"><a href="/wiki/File:WWImontage.jpg" class="image"><img alt="WWImontage.jpg" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/20/WWImontage.jpg/300px-WWImontage.jpg" //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/20/WWImontage.jpg/600px-WWImontage.jpg 2x" data-file-width="799" data-file-height="828" /></a><br /><b>Clockwise from the top</b>: The aftermath of shelling during the <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_the_Somme" title="Battle of the Somme">Battle of the Somme</a>, <a href="/wiki/Mark_V_tank" title="Mark V tank">Mark V tanks</a> cross the <a href="/wiki/Hindenburg_Line" title="Hindenburg Line">Hindenburg Line</a>, <a href="/wiki/HMS_Irresistible_(1898)" title="HMS Irresistible (1898)">HMS&#160;<i>Irresistible</i></a> sinks after hitting a <a href="/wiki/Naval_mine" title="Naval mine">mine</a> in the <a href="/wiki/Naval_operations_in_the_Dardanelles_Campaign" title="Naval operations in the Dardanelles Campaign">Dardanelles</a>, a British <a href="/wiki/Vickers_machine_gun" title="Vickers machine gun">Vickers machine gun</a> crew wears <a href="/wiki/Gas_mask" title="Gas mask">gas masks</a> during the Battle of the Somme, <a href="/wiki/Albatros_D.III" title="Albatros D.III">Albatros D.III</a> fighters of <a href="/wiki/Jagdstaffel_11" title="Jagdstaffel 11">Jagdstaffel 11</a></td></tr><tr><td colspan="2"><table style="width:100%;margin:0;padding:0;border:0"><tbody><tr><th style="padding-right:1em">Date</th><td>28&#160;July&#160;1914&#160;\xe2\x80\x93 11&#160;November&#160;1918<span style="display:none">&#160;(<span class="dtstart">1914-07-28</span>&#160;\xe2\x80\x93 <span class="dtend">1918-11-11</span>)</span><br />(4&#160;years, 3&#160;months and 2&#160;weeks)\n<div class="NavFrame collapsed" style="border: none; padding: 0;">\n<div class="NavHead" style="font-size: 105%; background: transparent; text-align: left;">Peace treaties</div>\n<ul class="NavContent" September 1919<br />(5&#160;years, 1&#160;month, 1&#160;week and 6&#160;days)\n</li><li style="line-height: inherit; margin: 0"><a href="/wiki/Treaty_of_Neuilly-sur-Seine" title="Treaty of />(5&#160;years, 10&#160;months and 1&#160;week)\n</li><li style="line-height: inherit; margin: 0"><a href="/wiki/Treaty_of_S%C3%A8vres" title="Treaty of S\xc3\xa8vres">Treaty of S\xc3\xa8vres</a><br 1923<br />(8&#160;years, 8&#160;months, 3&#160;weeks and 4&#160;days)<sup id="cite_ref-8" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-8">&#91;h&#93;</a></sup>\n</li></ul>\n</div></td></tr><tr><th style="padding-right:1em">Location</th><td><span class="location">Europe, Africa, the Middle East, the <a href="/wiki/Pacific_Islands" title="Pacific Islands">Pacific Islands</a>, China, Indian Ocean, and off the coast of South and North America</span></td></tr><tr><th style="padding-right:1em">Result</th><td>\n<p><a href="/wiki/Allies_of_World_War_I" title="Allies of World War I">Allied Powers</a> victory\n</p>\n<ul><li><a href="/wiki/Central_Powers" title="Central Powers">Central Powers</a>\' victory on the <a href="/wiki/Eastern_Front_(World_War_I)" title="Eastern Front (World War I)">Eastern Front</a> nullified by defeat on the <a href="/wiki/Western_Front_(World_War_I)" title="Western Front (World War I)">Western Front</a></li>\n<li>Fall of all of the continental European (<a href="/wiki/German_Empire" title="German Empire">German</a>, <a href="/wiki/Russian_Empire" title="Russian Empire">Russian</a>, <a href="/wiki/Ottoman_Empire" title="Ottoman Empire">Ottoman</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Austria-Hungary" title="Austria-Hungary">Austro-Hungarian</a>) empires</li>\n<li><a href="/wiki/Russian_Civil_War" title="Russian Civil War">Russian Civil War</a> and foundation of the <a href="/wiki/Soviet_Union" title="Soviet Union">Soviet Union</a></li>\n<li>Establishment of the <a href="/wiki/League_of_Nations" title="League of Nations">League of Nations</a> (<a href="/wiki/World_War_I#Aftermath" title="World War I">more...</a>)</li></ul></td></tr><tr><th style="padding-right:1em">Territorial<br />changes</th><td>\n<li>Formation of new countries in Europe and the Middle East</li>\n<li>Transfer of <a href="/wiki/German_colonies" class="mw-redirect" title="German colonies">German colonies</a> and <a href="/wiki/Partitioning_of_the_Ottoman_Empire" colspan="2" style="background-color:#C3D6EF;text-align:center;vertical-align:middle;font-size:110%;">Casualties and losses</th></tr><tr><td style="width:50%;border-right:1px dotted #aaa;">\n<div class="plainlist">\n<ul><li><b>Military dead:</b> 5,525,000</li>\n<li><b>Military wounded:</b> 12,831,500</li>\n<li><b>Total:</b> 18,356,500&#160;KIA, WIA and MIA</li>\n<li><b>Civilian dead:</b> 4,000,000</li></ul>\n</div>\n<p><span style="font-size:85%;"><a href="/wiki/World_War_I_casualties" title="World War I casualties">...<i>further details</i>.</a></span>\n</p>\n<hr />\n<p><span href="/wiki/Anglo-Russian_Convention" title="Anglo-Russian Convention">Anglo-Russian Entente</a></td><td style="text-align:right;">1907</td></tr><tr style="vertical-align:top"><td style="text-align:left;"><a href="/wiki/Bosnian_crisis" title="Bosnian crisis">Bosnian crisis</a></td><td style="text-align:right;">1908&#8211;1909</td></tr><tr style="vertical-align:top"><td style="text-align:left;"><a href="/wiki/Agadir_Crisis" title="Agadir Crisis">Agadir Crisis</a></td><td style="text-align:right;">1911</td></tr><tr style="vertical-align:top"><td style="text-align:left;"><a href="/wiki/Italo-Turkish_War" title="Italo-Turkish War">Italo-Turkish War</a></td><td style="text-align:right;">1911&#8211;1912</td></tr><tr style="vertical-align:top"><td style="text-align:left;"><a href="/wiki/Balkan_Wars" title="Balkan Wars">Balkan Wars</a></td><td style="text-align:right;">1912&#8211;1913</td></tr><tr style="vertical-align:top"><td style="text-align:left;"><a href="/wiki/Assassination_of_Archduke_Franz_Ferdinand" title="Assassination of Archduke Franz Ferdinand">Assassination of Franz Ferdinand</a></td><td style="text-align:right;">1914</td></tr><tr style="vertical-align:top"><td style="text-align:left;"><a href="/wiki/July_Crisis" title="July Crisis">July Crisis</a></td><td style="text-align:right;">1914</td></tr></tbody></table></td>\n</tr><tr><td style="text-align:right;font-size:115%"><div class="plainlinks hlist navbar mini"><ul><li class="nv-view"><a href="/wiki/Template:Events_leading_to_World_War_I" title="Template:Events leading to World War I"><abbr title="View this template">v</abbr></a></li><li class="nv-talk"><a href="/wiki/Template_talk:Events_leading_to_World_War_I" title="Template talk:Events leading to World War I"><abbr title="Discuss this template">t</abbr></a></li><li class="nv-edit"><a class="external text" href="//en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Template:Events_leading_to_World_War_I&amp;action=edit"><abbr title="Edit this template">e</abbr></a></li></ul></div></td></tr></tbody></table>\n<p><b>World War I</b> (often abbreviated as <b>WWI</b> or <b>WW1</b>), also known as the <b>First World War</b> or the <b>Great War</b>, was a <a href="/wiki/World_war" title="World war">global war</a> originating in <a href="/wiki/Europe" title="Europe">Europe</a> that lasted from 28 July 1914 to 11 November 1918. Contemporaneously described as the "<a href="/wiki/The_war_to_end_war" title="The war to end war">war to end all wars</a>",<sup id="cite_ref-15" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-15">&#91;7&#93;</a></sup> more than 70&#160;million <a href="/wiki/Military_personnel" title="Military personnel">military personnel</a>, including 60 million Europeans, were mobilised in one of the largest wars in history.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKeegan19988_16-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKeegan19988-16">&#91;8&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBadeBrown2003167\xe2\x80\x93168_17-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBadeBrown2003167\xe2\x80\x93168-17">&#91;9&#93;</a></sup> An estimated nine million <a href="/wiki/Combatants" class="mw-redirect" title="Combatants">combatants</a> and seven million <a href="/wiki/Civilian" title="Civilian">civilians</a> <a href="/wiki/World_War_I_casualties" title="World War I casualties">died as a direct result of the war</a>, while it is also considered a contributory factor in a <a href="/wiki/Genocides_in_history#World_War_I_through_World_War_II" title="Genocides in history">number of genocides</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Spanish_flu" title="Spanish flu">1918 influenza epidemic</a>, which caused between 50 to 100 million deaths worldwide.<sup id="cite_ref-18" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-18">&#91;10&#93;</a></sup> Military losses were exacerbated by new technological and industrial developments and the tactical stalemate caused by gruelling <a href="/wiki/Trench_warfare" title="Trench warfare">trench warfare</a>. It was <a href="/wiki/List_of_wars_and_anthropogenic_disasters_by_death_toll" title="List of wars and anthropogenic disasters by death toll">one of the deadliest conflicts in history</a> and precipitated major political changes, including the <a href="/wiki/Revolutions_of_1917%E2%80%931923" title="Revolutions of 1917\xe2\x80\x931923">Revolutions of 1917\xe2\x80\x931923</a>, in many of the nations involved. \n</p><p>By 1914, the European powers were divided into two coalitions: the <a href="/wiki/Triple_Entente" title="Triple Entente">Triple Entente</a>, consisting of <a href="/wiki/French_Third_Republic" title="French Third Republic">France</a>, <a href="/wiki/Russian_Empire" title="Russian Empire">Russia</a> and <a href="/wiki/British_Empire" title="British Empire">Britain</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Triple_Alliance_(1882)" title="Triple Alliance (1882)">Triple Alliance</a> of <a href="/wiki/German_Empire" title="German Empire">Germany</a>, <a href="/wiki/Austria-Hungary" title="Austria-Hungary">Austria-Hungary</a> and <a href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_Italy" title="Kingdom of Italy">Italy</a>. The Triple Alliance was primarily defensive in nature, allowing Italy to stay out of the war in 1914, while many of the terms of both agreements were informal and contradicted by others; for example, Italy renewed the Triple Alliance in 1902 but secretly agreed with France to remain neutral if it was attacked by Germany.<sup id="cite_ref-Seymour_19-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Seymour-19">&#91;11&#93;</a></sup> As the war widened, the Entente added Italy, <a href="/wiki/Empire_of_Japan" title="Empire of Japan">Japan</a> and eventually the <a href="/wiki/United_States" title="United States">United States</a> to form the <a href="/wiki/Allies_of_World_War_I" title="Allies of World War I">Allied Powers</a>, while the <a href="/wiki/Ottoman_Empire" title="Ottoman Empire">Ottoman Empire</a> and <a href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_Bulgaria" title="Kingdom of Bulgaria">Bulgaria</a> joined Germany and Austria to create the <a href="/wiki/Central_Powers" title="Central Powers">Central Powers</a>. \n</p><p>Between 1908 and 1914, the <a href="/wiki/Balkans" title="Balkans">Balkans</a> had been destabilised by the combination of a weakened Ottoman Empire, the 1912\xe2\x80\x931913 <a href="/wiki/Balkan_Wars" title="Balkan Wars">Balkan Wars</a> and competing Russian and Austro-Hungarian objectives.<sup id="cite_ref-20" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-20">&#91;12&#93;</a></sup> On 28 June 1914, <a href="/wiki/Gavrilo_Princip" title="Gavrilo Princip">Gavrilo Princip</a>, a <a href="/wiki/Serbs_of_Bosnia_and_Herzegovina" title="Serbs of Bosnia and Herzegovina">Bosnian Serb</a> <a href="/wiki/Yugoslavism" title="Yugoslavism">Yugoslav</a> nationalist, <a href="/wiki/Assassination_of_Archduke_Franz_Ferdinand" title="Assassination of Archduke Franz Ferdinand">assassinated</a> the Austro-Hungarian heir <a href="/wiki/Archduke_Franz_Ferdinand_of_Austria" title="Archduke Franz Ferdinand of Austria">Archduke Franz Ferdinand</a> in <a href="/wiki/Sarajevo" title="Sarajevo">Sarajevo</a>, leading to a <a href="/wiki/July_Crisis" title="July Crisis">diplomatic crisis</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-AJPT2_21-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-AJPT2-21">&#91;13&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDjoki\xc4\x87200324_22-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDjoki\xc4\x87200324-22">&#91;14&#93;</a></sup> On 23 July, Austria-Hungary issued an ultimatum to <a href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_Serbia" title="Kingdom of Serbia">Serbia</a>; interlocking alliances quickly drew in all the major European powers with their respective colonial empires and the conflict rapidly spread across the globe.\n</p><p>On 25 July, the Russian government issued orders for the \'period preparatory to war\'; after Austria-Hungary shelled the Serbian capital of <a href="/wiki/Belgrade" title="Belgrade">Belgrade</a> on the 28th, partial mobilisation was approved of the military districts nearest to Austria, including Kiev, Kazan, Odessa and Moscow.<sup id="cite_ref-23" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-23">&#91;15&#93;</a></sup> General Russian mobilisation was announced on the evening of 30 July; on the 31st, Austria-Hungary and Germany did the same, while Germany demanded Russia demobilise within 12 hours.<sup id="cite_ref-24" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-24">&#91;16&#93;</a></sup> When Russia failed to comply, Germany declared war on 1 August, with Austria-Hungary following suit on 6th; France ordered full mobilisation in support of Russia on 2 August.<sup id="cite_ref-25" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-25">&#91;17&#93;</a></sup> French entry into the war stemmed from a combination of the desire to regain the provinces of <a href="/wiki/Alsace-Lorraine" title="Alsace-Lorraine">Alsace-Lorraine</a> ceded after the 1870\xe2\x80\x931871 <a href="/wiki/Franco-Prussian_War" title="Franco-Prussian War">Franco-Prussian War</a>, concern at Germany\'s increasing power and military commitments agreed with Russia.<sup id="cite_ref-26" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-26">&#91;18&#93;</a></sup> \n</p><p>German strategy for a war on two fronts against France and Russia was to concentrate the bulk of their army in the West to defeat France within four weeks, then shift forces to the East before Russia could fully mobilise; this was later known as the <a href="/wiki/Schlieffen_Plan" title="Schlieffen Plan">Schlieffen Plan</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-27" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-27">&#91;19&#93;</a></sup> On 2 August, Germany demanded <a href="/wiki/German_invasion_of_Belgium" title="German invasion of Belgium">free passage through Belgium</a>, an essential element in achieving a quick victory over France.<sup id="cite_ref-28" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-28">&#91;20&#93;</a></sup> When this was refused, German forces entered Belgium early on the morning of 3 August and declared war with France the same day; the Belgian government invoked the <a href="/wiki/Treaty_of_London_(1839)" title="Treaty of London (1839)">1839 Treaty of London</a> and in compliance with its obligations under this, Britain declared war on Germany on 4 August.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEEvans200412_29-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEEvans200412-29">&#91;21&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMartel2003xii_ff_30-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMartel2003xii_ff-30">&#91;22&#93;</a></sup> On 12 August, Britain and France also declared war on Austria-Hungary; on the 23rd, the Empire of Japan joined the Allied Powers, seizing the opportunity to expand its sphere of influence by capturing German possessions in <a href="/wiki/Republic_of_China_(1912-1949)" class="mw-redirect" title="Republic of China (1912-1949)">China</a> and the Pacific. On 24 August, Serbia won a major victory over the Austro-Hungarians at the <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Cer" title="Battle of Cer">Battle of Cer</a>.\n</p><p>The German advance into France was halted at the <a href="/wiki/First_Battle_of_the_Marne" title="First Battle of the Marne">Battle of the Marne</a> and by the end of 1914, the <a href="/wiki/Western_Front_(World_War_I)" title="Western Front (World War I)">Western Front</a> settled into a <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_attrition" class="mw-redirect" title="Battle of attrition">battle of attrition</a>, marked by a long series of <a href="/wiki/Trench_warfare" title="Trench warfare">trench lines</a> that changed little until 1917. On the <a href="/wiki/Eastern_Front_(World_War_I)" title="Eastern Front (World War I)">Eastern Front</a>, two Russian armies entered <a href="/wiki/East_Prussia" title="East Prussia">East Prussia</a> on 17 August, in compliance with their 1912 agreement with France to attack Germany within 15 days of mobilisation.<sup id="cite_ref-31" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-31">&#91;23&#93;</a></sup> The Germans were forced to divert troops from the West but successfully repulsed this invasion by victories at <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Tannenberg" title="Battle of Tannenberg">Tannenberg</a> and the <a href="/wiki/First_Battle_of_the_Masurian_Lakes" title="First Battle of the Masurian Lakes">Masurian Lakes</a>; however, the Russians occupied the Austro-Hungarian province of <a href="/wiki/Russian_occupation_of_Eastern_Galicia,_1914%E2%80%9315" title="Russian occupation of Eastern Galicia, 1914\xe2\x80\x9315">Eastern Galicia</a>.\n</p><p>In November 1914, the Ottoman Empire joined the Central Powers, opening fronts in the <a href="/wiki/Caucasus" title="Caucasus">Caucasus</a>, <a href="/wiki/Mesopotamia" title="Mesopotamia">Mesopotamia</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Sinai_Peninsula" title="Sinai Peninsula">Sinai Peninsula</a>. In 1915, Italy joined the Allied Powers and Bulgaria joined the Central Powers. <a href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_Romania" title="Kingdom of Romania">Romania</a> joined the Allied Powers in 1916. After the sinking of seven US merchant ships by German submarines, and <a href="/wiki/Zimmermann_Telegram" title="Zimmermann Telegram">the revelation</a> that the Germans were trying to incite Mexico to make war on the United States, the <a href="/wiki/United_States_declaration_of_war_on_Germany_(1917)" title="United States declaration of war on Germany (1917)">US declared war on Germany</a> on 6 April 1917.\n</p><p>The Russian government collapsed in March 1917 with the <a href="/wiki/February_Revolution" title="February Revolution">February Revolution</a>, and the <a href="/wiki/October_Revolution" title="October Revolution">October Revolution</a> followed by a further military defeat brought the Russians to terms with the Central Powers via the <a href="/wiki/Treaty_of_Brest-Litovsk" title="Treaty of Brest-Litovsk">Treaty of Brest-Litovsk</a>, which granted the Germans a significant victory. After the stunning German <a href="/wiki/Spring_Offensive" title="Spring Offensive">Spring Offensive</a> along the Western Front in the spring of 1918, the Allied Powers rallied and drove back the Germans in the successful <a href="/wiki/Hundred_Days_Offensive" title="Hundred Days Offensive">Hundred Days Offensive</a>. On 4 November 1918, the Austro-Hungarian empire agreed to the <a href="/wiki/Armistice_of_Villa_Giusti" title="Armistice of Villa Giusti">Armistice of Villa Giusti</a>, and Germany, which had <a href="/wiki/German_Revolution_of_1918%E2%80%9319" title="German Revolution of 1918\xe2\x80\x9319">its own trouble with revolutionaries</a>, agreed to an armistice on 11 November 1918, ending the war in victory for the Allied Powers.\n</p><p>The war resulted in the demise of Tsarist Russia and the dissolution of the German, Austro-Hungarian and Ottoman Empires, with national borders being redrawn throughout Europe and the Middle East. In the 1919 <a href="/wiki/Paris_Peace_Conference,_1919" title="Paris Peace Conference, 1919">Paris Peace Conference</a>, Britain, France, the United States and Italy or the <a href="/wiki/The_Big_Four_(World_War_I)" title="The Big Four (World War I)">Four Powers</a> imposed their terms in a series of treaties. It also resulted in the formation of the <a href="/wiki/League_of_Nations" title="League of Nations">League of Nations</a>; this was intended to prevent another such conflict, but for a variety of reasons failed to resolve the issues that would ultimately lead to <a href="/wiki/World_War_II" title="World War II">World War II</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEWillmott2003307_32-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWillmott2003307-32">&#91;24&#93;</a></sup>\n</p>\n<div id="toc" class="toc"><input type="checkbox" role="button" id="toctogglecheckbox" class="toctogglecheckbox" style="display:none" /><div class="toctitle" lang="en" dir="ltr"><h2>Contents</h2><span class="toctogglespan"><label class="toctogglelabel" class="toctext">Russian Revolution</span></a></li>\n<li class="toclevel-3 tocsection-30"><a href="#Czechoslovak_Legion"><span class="tocnumber">4.5.3</span> <span class="toctext">Czechoslovak Legion</span></a></li>\n</ul>\n</li>\n<li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-31"><a href="#Central_Powers_peace_overtures"><span class="tocnumber">4.6</span> <span class="toctext">Central Powers peace overtures</span></a></li>\n<li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-32"><a href="#1917\xe2\x80\x931918"><span class="tocnumber">4.7</span> <span class="toctext">1917\xe2\x80\x931918</span></a>\n<ul>\n<li class="toclevel-3 tocsection-33"><a href="#Developments_in_1917"><span class="tocnumber">4.7.1</span> <span class="toctext">Developments in 1917</span></a></li>\n<li class="toclevel-3 Pope</span></a></li>\n<li class="toclevel-3 tocsection-36"><a href="#Entry_of_the_United_States"><span class="tocnumber">4.7.4</span> <span class="toctext">Entry of the United 1918</span></a></li>\n<li class="toclevel-3 tocsection-38"><a href="#New_states_enter_the_war"><span class="tocnumber">4.7.6</span> <span class="toctext">New states enter the war</span></a></li>\n</ul>\n</li>\n<li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-39"><a href="#Allied_victory:_summer_1918_onwards"><span class="tocnumber">4.8</span> <span class="toctext">Allied victory: summer 1918 onwards</span></a>\n<ul>\n<li class="toclevel-3 tocsection-40"><a href="#Hundred_Days_Offensive"><span class="tocnumber">4.8.1</span> <span class="toctext">Hundred Days Offensive</span></a></li>\n<li class="toclevel-3 tocsection-41"><a href="#Armistices_and_capitulations"><span class="tocnumber">4.8.2</span> <span class="toctext">Armistices and capitulations</span></a></li>\n</ul>\n</li>\n</ul>\n</li>\n<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-42"><a href="#Aftermath"><span class="tocnumber">5</span> <span war</span></a></li>\n<li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-44"><a href="#Peace_treaties_and_national_boundaries"><span class="tocnumber">5.2</span> <span class="toctext">Peace treaties and national boundaries</span></a></li>\n<li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-45"><a href="#National_identities"><span class="tocnumber">5.3</span> <span class="toctext">National identities</span></a></li>\n<li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-46"><a href="#Health_effects"><span class="tocnumber">5.4</span> <span class="toctext">Health effects</span></a></li>\n</ul>\n</li>\n<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-47"><a href="#Technology"><span class="tocnumber">6</span> <span class="toctext">Technology</span></a>\n<ul>\n<li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-48"><a href="#Ground_warfare"><span class="tocnumber">6.1</span> <span class="toctext">Ground warfare</span></a>\n<ul>\n<li class="toclevel-3 tocsection-49"><a href="#Areas_taken_in_major_attacks"><span class="tocnumber">6.1.1</span> <span class="toctext">Areas taken in major attacks</span></a></li>\n</ul>\n</li>\n<li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-50"><a href="#Naval"><span class="tocnumber">6.2</span> <span class="toctext">Naval</span></a></li>\n<li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-51"><a href="#Aviation"><span class="tocnumber">6.3</span> <span class="toctext">Aviation</span></a></li>\n</ul>\n</li>\n<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-52"><a href="#War_crimes"><span class="tocnumber">7</span> <span class="toctext">War crimes</span></a>\n<ul>\n<li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-53"><a href="#Baralong_incidents"><span class="tocnumber">7.1</span> <span class="toctext">Baralong incidents</span></a></li>\n<li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-54"><a href="#Torpedoing_of_HMHS_Llandovery_Castle"><span class="tocnumber">7.2</span> <span class="toctext">Torpedoing of HMHS <i>Llandovery Castle</i></span></a></li>\n<li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-55"><a href="#Chemical_weapons_in_warfare"><span class="tocnumber">7.3</span> <span class="toctext">Chemical weapons in warfare</span></a></li>\n<li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-56"><a href="#Genocide_and_ethnic_cleansing"><span class="tocnumber">7.4</span> <span class="toctext">Genocide and ethnic cleansing</span></a>\n<ul>\n<li class="toclevel-3 tocsection-57"><a href="#Russian_Empire"><span class="tocnumber">7.4.1</span> <span class="toctext">Russian Empire</span></a></li>\n</ul>\n</li>\n<li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-58"><a href="#Rape_of_Belgium"><span class="tocnumber">7.5</span> <span class="toctext">Rape of Belgium</span></a></li>\n</ul>\n</li>\n<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-59"><a href="#Soldiers&#39;_experiences"><span class="tocnumber">8</span> <span class="toctext">Soldiers\' experiences</span></a>\n<ul>\n<li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-60"><a href="#Prisoners_of_war"><span class="tocnumber">8.1</span> <span class="toctext">Prisoners of war</span></a></li>\n<li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-61"><a href="#Military_attach\xc3\xa9s_and_war_correspondents"><span class="tocnumber">8.2</span> <span class="toctext">Military attach\xc3\xa9s and war correspondents</span></a></li>\n</ul>\n</li>\n<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-62"><a href="#Support_and_opposition_to_the_war"><span class="tocnumber">9</span> <span class="toctext">Support and opposition to the war</span></a>\n<ul>\n<li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-63"><a href="#Support"><span class="tocnumber">9.1</span> <span class="toctext">Support</span></a></li>\n<li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-64"><a href="#Opposition"><span class="tocnumber">9.2</span> <span class="toctext">Opposition</span></a>\n<ul>\n<li class="toclevel-3 tocsection-65"><a href="#Conscription"><span class="tocnumber">9.2.1</span> <span class="toctext">Conscription</span></a></li>\n<li class="toclevel-3 tocsection-66"><a href="#Conscription_in_Canada"><span class="tocnumber">9.2.2</span> <span class="toctext">Conscription in Canada</span></a></li>\n<li class="toclevel-3 tocsection-67"><a href="#Conscription_in_Australia"><span class="tocnumber">9.2.3</span> <span class="toctext">Conscription in Australia</span></a></li>\n<li class="toclevel-3 tocsection-68"><a href="#Conscription_in_Britain"><span class="tocnumber">9.2.4</span> <span class="toctext">Conscription in Britain</span></a></li>\n<li class="toclevel-3 tocsection-69"><a href="#United_States"><span class="tocnumber">9.2.5</span> <span class="toctext">United States</span></a></li>\n<li class="toclevel-3 tocsection-70"><a href="#Austria-Hungary"><span class="tocnumber">9.2.6</span> <span class="toctext">Austria-Hungary</span></a></li>\n</ul>\n</li>\n<li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-71"><a href="#Diplomacy"><span class="tocnumber">9.3</span> <span class="toctext">Diplomacy</span></a></li>\n</ul>\n</li>\n<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-72"><a href="#Legacy_and_memory"><span class="tocnumber">10</span> <span class="toctext">Legacy and memory</span></a>\n<ul>\n<li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-73"><a href="#Historiography"><span class="tocnumber">10.1</span> <span class="toctext">Historiography</span></a></li>\n<li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-74"><a href="#Memorials"><span class="tocnumber">10.2</span> <span class="toctext">Memorials</span></a></li>\n<li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-75"><a href="#Cultural_memory"><span class="tocnumber">10.3</span> <span class="toctext">Cultural memory</span></a></li>\n<li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-76"><a href="#Social_trauma"><span class="tocnumber">10.4</span> <span class="toctext">Social trauma</span></a></li>\n<li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-77"><a href="#Discontent_in_Germany"><span class="tocnumber">10.5</span> <span class="toctext">Discontent in Germany</span></a></li>\n<li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-78"><a href="#Economic_effects"><span class="tocnumber">10.6</span> <span class="toctext">Economic effects</span></a></li>\n</ul>\n</li>\n<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-79"><a href="#See_also"><span class="tocnumber">11</span> <span class="toctext">See also</span></a></li>\n<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-80"><a href="#Footnotes"><span class="tocnumber">12</span> <span class="toctext">Footnotes</span></a></li>\n<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-81"><a href="#References"><span class="tocnumber">13</span> <span class="toctext">References</span></a></li>\n<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-82"><a href="#Bibliography"><span class="tocnumber">14</span> <span class="toctext">Bibliography</span></a>\n<ul>\n<li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-83"><a href="#Primary_sources"><span class="tocnumber">14.1</span> <span class="toctext">Primary sources</span></a></li>\n<li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-84"><a href="#Historiography_and_memory"><span class="tocnumber">14.2</span> <span class="toctext">Historiography and memory</span></a></li>\n</ul>\n</li>\n<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-85"><a href="#External_links"><span class="tocnumber">15</span> <span class="toctext">External links</span></a>\n<ul>\n<li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-86"><a href="#Animated_maps"><span class="tocnumber">15.1</span> <span class="toctext">Animated maps</span></a></li>\n<li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-87"><a href="#Library_guides"><span class="tocnumber">15.2</span> <span class="toctext">Library guides</span></a></li>\n</ul>\n</li>\n</ul>\n</div>\n\n<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Names">Names</span></h2>\n<p>The term "First World War" was first used in September 1914 by German biologist and philosopher <a href="/wiki/Ernst_Haeckel" title="Ernst Haeckel">Ernst Haeckel</a>, who claimed that "there is no doubt that the course and character of the feared \'European War\'&#160;... will become the first world war in the full sense of the word,"<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEShapiroEpstein2006329_33-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEShapiroEpstein2006329-33">&#91;25&#93;</a></sup> citing a wire service report in <i><a href="/wiki/The_Indianapolis_Star" title="The Indianapolis Star">The Indianapolis Star</a></i> on 20 September 1914.\n</p><p>Prior to <a href="/wiki/World_War_II" title="World War II">World War II</a>, the events of 1914\xe2\x80\x931918 were generally known as the <b>Great War</b> or simply the <b>World War</b>.<sup id="cite_ref-34" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-34">&#91;26&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBraybon20048_35-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBraybon20048-35">&#91;27&#93;</a></sup> Contemporary Europeans also referred to it as "<a href="/wiki/The_war_to_end_war" title="The war to end war">the war to end war</a>" or "the war to end all wars" due to their perception of its then-unparalleled scale and devastation.<sup id="cite_ref-36" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-36">&#91;28&#93;</a></sup> After World War II began in 1939, the terms became more standard, with British Empire historians, including Canadians, favouring "The First World War" and Americans "World War I".<sup id="cite_ref-37" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-37">&#91;29&#93;</a></sup>\n</p><p>In October 1914, the Canadian magazine <i><a href="/wiki/Maclean%27s" title="Maclean&#39;s">Maclean\'s</a></i> wrote, "Some wars name themselves. This is the Great War."<sup id="cite_ref-38" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-38">&#91;30&#93;</a></sup> However, while certainly accurate in Canada, this was not so even in Britain; historian <a href="/wiki/John_Holland_Rose" title="John Holland Rose">John Holland Rose</a>\'s 1911 account of the 1793\xe2\x80\x931815 wars against France was titled <i>William Pitt and the Great War</i>.<sup id="cite_ref-39" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-39">&#91;31&#93;</a></sup> This was validated by Gareth Glover\'s 2015 book, <i>Waterloo in 100 Objects</i>, in which he states: "This opening statement will cause some bewilderment to many who have grown up with the appellation of the Great War firmly applied to the 1914\xe2\x80\x9318 First World War. But to anyone living before 1918, the title of the Great War was applied to the <a href="/wiki/French_Revolutionary_Wars" title="French Revolutionary Wars">Revolutionary</a> and <a href="/wiki/Napoleonic_Wars" title="Napoleonic Wars">Napoleonic</a> wars in which Britain fought France almost continuously for twenty-two years from 1793 to 1815."<sup id="cite_ref-40" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-40">&#91;32&#93;</a></sup>\n</p><p>In Germany, "The Great War" was historically used for the <a href="/wiki/Thirty_Years%27_War" title="Thirty Years&#39; War">1618\xe2\x80\x931648 Thirty Years\' War</a>, also known as the "Great German War" or "Great Schism". One of the longest and most destructive conflicts in human history, it resulted in eight million fatalities from military action, violence, famine and plague, the vast majority of them in the German states of the <a href="/wiki/Holy_Roman_Empire" title="Holy Roman Empire">Holy Roman Empire</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-41" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-41">&#91;33&#93;</a></sup> In terms of proportional German casualties and destruction, it was only surpassed by the period from January to May 1945; its enduring visibility is partly the result of 19th-century <a href="/wiki/Pan-Germanism" title="Pan-Germanism">Pan-Germanism</a>, as an example of the dangers of a divided Germany and a driver in the 1871 creation of the <i lang="de" title="German language text">Deutsches Kaiserreich</i> or <a href="/wiki/German_Empire" title="German Empire">German Empire</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-42" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-42">&#91;34&#93;</a></sup> Regardless of terminology, the Thirty Years\' War remains the single greatest war trauma in German memory, as demonstrated in debates over naming conventions during the centenary of 1914\xe2\x80\x931918.<sup id="cite_ref-43" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-43">&#91;35&#93;</a></sup>\n</p>\n<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Background">Background</span></h2>\n<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Causes_of_World_War_I" title="Causes of World War I">Causes of World War I</a></div>\n<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Political_and_military_alliances">Political and military alliances</span></h3>\n<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:312px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Map_Europe_alliances_1914-en.svg" class="image"><img alt="Map of Europe focusing on Austria-Hungary and marking central location of ethnic groups in it including Slovaks, Czechs, Slovenes, Croats, Serbs, Romanians, Ukrainians, Poles." src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/26/Map_Europe_alliances_1914-en.svg/310px-Map_Europe_alliances_1914-en.svg.png" width="310" height="183" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/26/Map_Europe_alliances_1914-en.svg/465px-Map_Europe_alliances_1914-en.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/26/Map_Europe_alliances_1914-en.svg/620px-Map_Europe_alliances_1914-en.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="1002" data-file-height="593" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Map_Europe_alliances_1914-en.svg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Rival military coalitions in 1914: <a href="/wiki/Triple_Entente" title="Triple Entente">Triple Entente</a> in green; <a href="/wiki/Triple_Alliance_(1882)" title="Triple Alliance (1882)">Triple Alliance</a> in brown. Only the Triple Alliance was a formal "alliance"; the others listed were informal patterns of support.</div></div></div>\n<p>For much of the 19th century, the major European powers had tried to maintain a tenuous <a href="/wiki/Balance_of_power_(international_relations)" title="Balance of power (international relations)">balance of power</a> among themselves, resulting in a complex network of political and military alliances.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEClark2014121\xe2\x80\x93152_44-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEClark2014121\xe2\x80\x93152-44">&#91;36&#93;</a></sup> The biggest challenges to this were Britain\'s withdrawal into so-called <a href="/wiki/Splendid_isolation" title="Splendid isolation">splendid isolation</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Decline_of_the_Ottoman_Empire" class="mw-redirect" title="Decline of the Ottoman Empire">decline of the Ottoman Empire</a> and the post-1848 rise of <a href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_Prussia" title="Kingdom of Prussia">Prussia</a> under <a href="/wiki/Otto_von_Bismarck" title="Otto von Bismarck">Otto von Bismarck</a>. Victory in the 1866 <a href="/wiki/Austro-Prussian_War" title="Austro-Prussian War">Austro-Prussian War</a> established Prussian hegemony in Germany, while victory over France in the 1870\xe2\x80\x931871 <a href="/wiki/Franco-Prussian_War" title="Franco-Prussian War">Franco-Prussian War</a> <a href="/wiki/Unification_of_Germany" title="Unification of Germany">unified</a> the German states into a <a href="/wiki/German_Empire" title="German Empire">German Reich</a> under Prussian leadership.\n</p><p>In 1873, to isolate France and avoid a war on two fronts, Bismarck negotiated the <a href="/wiki/League_of_the_Three_Emperors" title="League of the Three Emperors">League of the Three Emperors</a> (German: <i>Dreikaiserbund</i>) between Austria-Hungary, Russia and Germany. Concerned by Russia\'s victory in the 1877\xe2\x80\x931878 <a href="/wiki/Russo-Turkish_War,_1877%E2%80%931878" class="mw-redirect" title="Russo-Turkish War, 1877\xe2\x80\x931878">Russo-Turkish War</a> and their influence in the <a href="/wiki/Balkans" title="Balkans">Balkans</a>, the League was dissolved in 1878, with Germany and Austria-Hungary subsequently forming the 1879 <a href="/wiki/Dual_Alliance,_1879" class="mw-redirect" title="Dual Alliance, 1879">Dual Alliance</a>; this became the <a href="/wiki/Triple_Alliance_(1882)" title="Triple Alliance (1882)">Triple Alliance</a> when Italy joined in 1882.<sup id="cite_ref-Willmott15_45-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Willmott15-45">&#91;37&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKeegan199852_46-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKeegan199852-46">&#91;38&#93;</a></sup>\n</p><p>The practical details of these alliances were limited, since their primary purpose was to ensure cooperation between the three Imperial Powers and isolate France. Attempts by Britain in 1880 to resolve colonial tensions with Russia and diplomatic moves by France led to Bismarck reforming the League in 1881.<sup id="cite_ref-47" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-47">&#91;39&#93;</a></sup> When the League finally lapsed in 1887, it was replaced by the <a href="/wiki/Reinsurance_Treaty" title="Reinsurance Treaty">Reinsurance Treaty</a>, a secret agreement between Germany and Russia to remain neutral if either were attacked by France or Austria-Hungary.\n</p><p>In 1890, the new German Emperor, <a href="/wiki/Wilhelm_II,_German_Emperor" title="Wilhelm II, German Emperor">Kaiser Wilhelm II</a>, forced Bismarck to retire and was persuaded not to renew the Reinsurance Treaty by the new <a href="/wiki/Chancellor_of_Germany" title="Chancellor of Germany">Chancellor</a>, <a href="/wiki/Leo_von_Caprivi" title="Leo von Caprivi">Leo von Caprivi</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-48" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-48">&#91;40&#93;</a></sup> This allowed France to counteract the Triple Alliance with the <a href="/wiki/Franco-Russian_Alliance" title="Franco-Russian Alliance">Franco-Russian Alliance</a> of 1894 and the 1904 <a href="/wiki/Entente_Cordiale" title="Entente Cordiale">Entente Cordiale</a> with Britain, while in 1907 Britain and Russia signed the <a href="/wiki/Anglo-Russian_Convention" title="Anglo-Russian Convention">Anglo-Russian Convention</a>. The agreements did not constitute formal alliances, but by settling long-standing colonial disputes, they made British entry into any future conflict involving France or Russia a possibility; these interlocking bilateral agreements became known as the <a href="/wiki/Triple_Entente" title="Triple Entente">Triple Entente</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Willmott15_45-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Willmott15-45">&#91;37&#93;</a></sup>\n</p>\n<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Arms_race">Arms race</span></h3>\n<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:202px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Bundesarchiv_DVM_10_Bild-23-61-23,_Linienschiff_%22SMS_Rheinland%22.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ee/Bundesarchiv_DVM_10_Bild-23-61-23%2C_Linienschiff_%22SMS_Rheinland%22.jpg/200px-Bundesarchiv_DVM_10_Bild-23-61-23%2C_Linienschiff_%22SMS_Rheinland%22.jpg" width="200" height="135" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ee/Bundesarchiv_DVM_10_Bild-23-61-23%2C_Linienschiff_%22SMS_Rheinland%22.jpg/300px-Bundesarchiv_DVM_10_Bild-23-61-23%2C_Linienschiff_%22SMS_Rheinland%22.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ee/Bundesarchiv_DVM_10_Bild-23-61-23%2C_Linienschiff_%22SMS_Rheinland%22.jpg/400px-Bundesarchiv_DVM_10_Bild-23-61-23%2C_Linienschiff_%22SMS_Rheinland%22.jpg 2x" data-file-width="800" data-file-height="538" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Bundesarchiv_DVM_10_Bild-23-61-23,_Linienschiff_%22SMS_Rheinland%22.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/SMS_Rheinland" title="SMS Rheinland">SMS&#160;<i>Rheinland</i></a>, a <a href="/wiki/Nassau-class_battleship" title="Nassau-class battleship"><i>Nassau</i>-class</a> battleship, Germany\'s first response to the British <i>Dreadnought</i></div></div></div>\n<p>Victory in the 1871 <a href="/wiki/Franco-Prussian_War" title="Franco-Prussian War">Franco-Prussian War</a> and the creation of the <a href="/wiki/German_Empire" title="German Empire">German Reich</a> led to a massive increase in Germany\'s economic and industrial strength. Admiral <a href="/wiki/Alfred_von_Tirpitz" title="Alfred von Tirpitz">Alfred von Tirpitz</a> and Wilhelm II, who became Emperor in 1890, sought to use that to create a <i>Kaiserliche Marine</i> or <a href="/wiki/Imperial_German_Navy" title="Imperial German Navy">Imperial German Navy</a> to compete with Britain\'s <a href="/wiki/Royal_Navy" title="Royal Navy">Royal Navy</a> for world naval supremacy.<sup id="cite_ref-willmott21_49-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-willmott21-49">&#91;41&#93;</a></sup> Their rationale was based on the ideas of US naval strategist <a href="/wiki/Alfred_Thayer_Mahan" title="Alfred Thayer Mahan">Alfred Mahan</a>, who argued that whoever ruled the sea also ruled the world; Tirpitz had Mahan\'s books translated into German, while Wilhelm made them required reading for his officers.<sup id="cite_ref-50" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-50">&#91;42&#93;</a></sup> However, Wilhelm annoyed his ministers by publicly declaring one motive to be his childhood admiration of the Royal Navy, which he had visited "with kind aunts and friendly admirals."<sup id="cite_ref-51" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-51">&#91;43&#93;</a></sup>   \n</p><p>The result was the <a href="/wiki/Anglo-German_naval_arms_race" title="Anglo-German naval arms race">Anglo-German naval arms race</a>. With the launch of <a href="/wiki/HMS_Dreadnought_(1906)" title="HMS Dreadnought (1906)">HMS&#160;<i>Dreadnought</i></a> in 1906, the Royal Navy increased its advantage over its German rival and continued to do so.<sup id="cite_ref-willmott21_49-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-willmott21-49">&#91;41&#93;</a></sup> By 1912, the German economy could no longer support both naval expansion and the largest permanent army in Europe, with Chancellor <a href="/wiki/Theobald_von_Bethmann-Hollweg" title="Theobald von Bethmann-Hollweg">Theobald von Bethmann-Hollweg</a> acknowledging defeat. In many ways, it was a strategic disaster for Germany, diverting huge resources to create a navy large enough to antagonise Britain but not defeat it.\n</p><p>Ending the naval arms race reduced tensions between Britain and Germany but did not lead to reductions elsewhere; in 1913, Germany approved an increase in its standing army by 170,000 men, Russia committed to another 500,000 men over the next three years, while France extended compulsory military service from two to three years. Between 1870 and 1914, total military spending by Austria, Germany, Italy, and Russia increased from <a href="/wiki/Pound_sterling" title="Pound sterling">\xc2\xa3</a>94 million to \xc2\xa3394 million (equivalent to \xc2\xa335 billion in 2016). The largest proportional increases occurred in Germany (+73%) and Russia (+39%).<sup id="cite_ref-52" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-52">&#91;44&#93;</a></sup>\n</p>\n<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Conflicts_in_the_Balkans">Conflicts in the Balkans</span></h3>\n<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:1908-10-07_-_Moritz_Schiller%27s_Delicatessen.jpg" class="image"><img alt="Photo of large white building with one signs saying &quot;Moritz Schiller&quot; and another in Arabic; in front is a cluster of people looking at poster on the wall." src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6a/1908-10-07_-_Moritz_Schiller%27s_Delicatessen.jpg/220px-1908-10-07_-_Moritz_Schiller%27s_Delicatessen.jpg" width="220" height="160" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6a/1908-10-07_-_Moritz_Schiller%27s_Delicatessen.jpg/330px-1908-10-07_-_Moritz_Schiller%27s_Delicatessen.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6a/1908-10-07_-_Moritz_Schiller%27s_Delicatessen.jpg/440px-1908-10-07_-_Moritz_Schiller%27s_Delicatessen.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1992" data-file-height="1445" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:1908-10-07_-_Moritz_Schiller%27s_Delicatessen.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Sarajevo citizens reading a poster with the proclamation of the <a href="/wiki/Bosnian_Crisis" class="mw-redirect" title="Bosnian Crisis">Austrian annexation in 1908</a></div></div></div>\n<p>In October 1908, Austria-Hungary precipitated the <a href="/wiki/Bosnian_crisis" title="Bosnian crisis">Bosnian crisis</a> of 1908\xe2\x80\x931909 by officially annexing the former Ottoman territory of <a href="/wiki/Bosnia_Vilayet" title="Bosnia Vilayet">Bosnia and Herzegovina</a>, which it <a href="/wiki/Austro-Hungarian_occupation_of_Bosnia_and_Herzegovina" class="mw-redirect" title="Austro-Hungarian occupation of Bosnia and Herzegovina">had occupied</a> since 1878. This angered the <a href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_Serbia" title="Kingdom of Serbia">Kingdom of Serbia</a> and its patron, the <a href="/wiki/Pan-Slavism" title="Pan-Slavism">Pan-Slavic</a> and <a href="/wiki/Eastern_Orthodox_Church" title="Eastern Orthodox Church">Orthodox</a> <a href="/wiki/Russian_Empire" title="Russian Empire">Russian Empire</a>. Russian political manoeuvring in the region destabilised peace accords that were already fracturing in the Balkans, which came to be known as the "<a href="/wiki/Powder_keg_of_Europe" title="Powder keg of Europe">powder keg of Europe</a>".<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKeegan199848\xe2\x80\x9349_53-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKeegan199848\xe2\x80\x9349-53">&#91;45&#93;</a></sup>\n</p><p>In 1912 and 1913, the <a href="/wiki/First_Balkan_War" title="First Balkan War">First Balkan War</a> was fought between the <a href="/wiki/Balkan_League" title="Balkan League">Balkan League</a> and the fracturing Ottoman Empire. The resulting <a href="/wiki/Treaty_of_London_(1913)" title="Treaty of London (1913)">Treaty of London</a> further shrank the Ottoman Empire, creating an independent <a href="/wiki/Albania" title="Albania">Albanian</a> state while enlarging the territorial holdings of Bulgaria, Serbia, <a href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_Montenegro" title="Kingdom of Montenegro">Montenegro</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_Greece" title="Kingdom of Greece">Greece</a>. When Bulgaria attacked Serbia and Greece on 16 June 1913, it sparked the 33-day <a href="/wiki/Second_Balkan_War" title="Second Balkan War">Second Balkan War</a>, by the end of which it lost most of <a href="/wiki/Macedonia_(region)" title="Macedonia (region)">Macedonia</a> to Serbia and Greece, and <a href="/wiki/Southern_Dobruja" title="Southern Dobruja">Southern Dobruja</a> to Romania, further destabilising the region.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEWillmott20032\xe2\x80\x9323_54-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWillmott20032\xe2\x80\x9323-54">&#91;46&#93;</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Great_Powers" class="mw-redirect" title="Great Powers">Great Powers</a> were able to keep these Balkan conflicts contained, but the next one would spread throughout Europe and beyond.\n</p>\n<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Prelude">Prelude</span></h2>\n<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Sarajevo_assassination">Sarajevo assassination</span></h3>\n<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Assassination_of_Archduke_Franz_Ferdinand_of_Austria" class="mw-redirect" title="Assassination of Archduke Franz Ferdinand of Austria">Assassination of Archduke Franz Ferdinand of Austria</a></div>\n<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Gavrilo_Princip_captured_in_Sarajevo_1914.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8a/Gavrilo_Princip_captured_in_Sarajevo_1914.jpg/220px-Gavrilo_Princip_captured_in_Sarajevo_1914.jpg" width="220" height="141" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8a/Gavrilo_Princip_captured_in_Sarajevo_1914.jpg/330px-Gavrilo_Princip_captured_in_Sarajevo_1914.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8a/Gavrilo_Princip_captured_in_Sarajevo_1914.jpg/440px-Gavrilo_Princip_captured_in_Sarajevo_1914.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1602" data-file-height="1028" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Gavrilo_Princip_captured_in_Sarajevo_1914.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>This picture is usually associated with the arrest of <a href="/wiki/Gavrilo_Princip" title="Gavrilo Princip">Gavrilo Princip</a>, although some<sup id="cite_ref-FinestoneMassie_55-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FinestoneMassie-55">&#91;47&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESmith2010_56-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESmith2010-56">&#91;48&#93;</a></sup> believe it depicts Ferdinand Behr, a bystander</div></div></div>\n<p>On 28 June 1914, <a href="/wiki/Archduke_Franz_Ferdinand_of_Austria" title="Archduke Franz Ferdinand of Austria">Archduke Franz Ferdinand</a>, heir presumptive to the <a href="/wiki/Austro-Hungarian_Empire" class="mw-redirect" title="Austro-Hungarian Empire">Austro-Hungarian Empire</a>, visited the <a href="/wiki/Bosnia_and_Herzegovina" title="Bosnia and Herzegovina">Bosnian</a> capital, <a href="/wiki/Sarajevo" title="Sarajevo">Sarajevo</a>. A group of six assassins (<a href="/wiki/Cvjetko_Popovi%C4%87" title="Cvjetko Popovi\xc4\x87">Cvjetko Popovi\xc4\x87</a>, <a href="/wiki/Gavrilo_Princip" title="Gavrilo Princip">Gavrilo Princip</a>, <a href="/wiki/Muhamed_Mehmedba%C5%A1i%C4%87" title="Muhamed Mehmedba\xc5\xa1i\xc4\x87">Muhamed Mehmedba\xc5\xa1i\xc4\x87</a>, <a href="/wiki/Nedeljko_%C4%8Cabrinovi%C4%87" title="Nedeljko \xc4\x8cabrinovi\xc4\x87">Nedeljko \xc4\x8cabrinovi\xc4\x87</a>, <a href="/wiki/Trifko_Grabe%C5%BE" title="Trifko Grabe\xc5\xbe">Trifko Grabe\xc5\xbe</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Vaso_%C4%8Cubrilovi%C4%87" title="Vaso \xc4\x8cubrilovi\xc4\x87">Vaso \xc4\x8cubrilovi\xc4\x87</a>) from the <a href="/wiki/Yugoslavism" title="Yugoslavism">Yugoslavist</a> group <a href="/wiki/Young_Bosnia" title="Young Bosnia">Mlada Bosna</a>, supplied by the Serbian <a href="/wiki/Black_Hand_(Serbia)" title="Black Hand (Serbia)">Black Hand</a>, gathered on the street where the Archduke\'s motorcade would pass, with the intention of assassinating him. \xc4\x8cabrinovi\xc4\x87 threw a <a href="/wiki/Hand_grenade" class="mw-redirect" title="Hand grenade">grenade</a> at the car, but missed. Some nearby were injured by the blast, but Ferdinand\'s convoy carried on. The other assassins failed to act as the cars drove past them.\n</p><p>About an hour later, when Ferdinand was returning from a visit at the Sarajevo Hospital with those wounded in the assassination attempt, the convoy took a wrong turn into a street where, by coincidence, Princip stood. With a pistol, Princip shot and killed Ferdinand and his wife <a href="/wiki/Sophie,_Duchess_of_Hohenberg" title="Sophie, Duchess of Hohenberg">Sophie</a>. The reaction among the people in Austria was mild, almost indifferent. As historian <a href="/wiki/Zbyn%C4%9Bk_Zeman" title="Zbyn\xc4\x9bk Zeman">Zbyn\xc4\x9bk Zeman</a> later wrote, "the event almost failed to make any impression whatsoever. On Sunday and Monday (28 and 29 June), the crowds in <a href="/wiki/Vienna" title="Vienna">Vienna</a> listened to music and drank wine, as if nothing had happened."<sup id="cite_ref-history_57-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-history-57">&#91;49&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEWillmott200326_58-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWillmott200326-58">&#91;50&#93;</a></sup> Nevertheless, the political impact of the murder of the heir to the throne was significant and has been described by historian <a href="/wiki/Christopher_Clark" title="Christopher Clark">Christopher Clark</a> on the BBC Radio 4 series <i>Month of Madness</i> as a "<a href="/wiki/September_11_attacks#Effects" title="September 11 attacks">9/11 effect</a>, a terrorist event charged with historic meaning, transforming the political chemistry in Vienna."<sup id="cite_ref-Christopher_Clark_2014_59-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Christopher_Clark_2014-59">&#91;51&#93;</a></sup> And although they were reportedly not personally close, the Emperor <a href="/wiki/Franz_Joseph_of_Austria" class="mw-redirect" title="Franz Joseph of Austria">Franz Joseph</a> was profoundly shocked and upset.\n</p>\n<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Expansion_of_violence_in_Bosnia_and_Herzegovina">Expansion of violence in Bosnia and Herzegovina</span></h3>\n<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:1914-06-29_-_Aftermath_of_attacks_against_Serbs_in_Sarajevo.png" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e6/1914-06-29_-_Aftermath_of_attacks_against_Serbs_in_Sarajevo.png/220px-1914-06-29_-_Aftermath_of_attacks_against_Serbs_in_Sarajevo.png" width="220" height="160" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e6/1914-06-29_-_Aftermath_of_attacks_against_Serbs_in_Sarajevo.png/330px-1914-06-29_-_Aftermath_of_attacks_against_Serbs_in_Sarajevo.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e6/1914-06-29_-_Aftermath_of_attacks_against_Serbs_in_Sarajevo.png/440px-1914-06-29_-_Aftermath_of_attacks_against_Serbs_in_Sarajevo.png 2x" data-file-width="911" data-file-height="664" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:1914-06-29_-_Aftermath_of_attacks_against_Serbs_in_Sarajevo.png" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Crowds on the streets in the aftermath of the <a href="/wiki/Anti-Serb_riots_in_Sarajevo" title="Anti-Serb riots in Sarajevo">anti-Serb riots in Sarajevo</a>, 29 June 1914</div></div></div>\n<p>The Austro-Hungarian authorities encouraged the subsequent <a href="/wiki/Anti-Serb_riots_in_Sarajevo" title="Anti-Serb riots in Sarajevo">anti-Serb riots in Sarajevo</a>, in which <a href="/wiki/Bosnian_Croats" class="mw-redirect" title="Bosnian Croats">Bosnian Croats</a> and <a href="/wiki/Bosniaks" title="Bosniaks">Bosniaks</a> killed two <a href="/wiki/Bosnian_Serbs" class="mw-redirect" title="Bosnian Serbs">Bosnian Serbs</a> and damaged numerous Serb-owned buildings.<sup id="cite_ref-Djordjevi\xc4\x87Spence1992_60-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Djordjevi\xc4\x87Spence1992-60">&#91;52&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-61" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-61">&#91;53&#93;</a></sup> Violent actions against ethnic Serbs were also organised outside Sarajevo, in other cities in Austro-Hungarian-controlled Bosnia and Herzegovina, Croatia and Slovenia. Austro-Hungarian authorities in Bosnia and Herzegovina imprisoned and extradited approximately 5,500 prominent Serbs, 700 to 2,200 of whom died in prison. A further 460 Serbs were sentenced to death. A predominantly Bosniak special militia known as the <i><a href="/wiki/Schutzkorps" title="Schutzkorps">Schutzkorps</a></i> was established and carried out the persecution of Serbs.<sup id="cite_ref-Kr\xc3\xb6ll2008_62-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Kr\xc3\xb6ll2008-62">&#91;54&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTETomasevich2001485_63-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTETomasevich2001485-63">&#91;55&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Schindler2007_64-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Schindler2007-64">&#91;56&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEVelikonja2003141_65-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEVelikonja2003141-65">&#91;57&#93;</a></sup>\n</p>\n<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="July_Crisis">July Crisis</span></h3>\n<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/July_Crisis" title="July Crisis">July Crisis</a></div>\n<p>The assassination led to a month of diplomatic manoeuvring between Austria-Hungary, Germany, Russia, France and Britain, called the <a href="/wiki/July_Crisis" title="July Crisis">July Crisis</a>. Austria-Hungary correctly believed that Serbian officials (especially the officers of the Black Hand) were involved in the plot to murder the Archduke, and wanted to finally end Serbian interference in Bosnia.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEStevenson199612_66-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEStevenson199612-66">&#91;58&#93;</a></sup> On 23 July, Austria-Hungary delivered to Serbia the <a href="/wiki/July_Crisis#Austro-Hungarian_ultimatum" title="July Crisis">July Ultimatum</a>, a series of ten demands that were made intentionally unacceptable, in an effort to provoke a war with Serbia.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEWillmott200327_67-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWillmott200327-67">&#91;59&#93;</a></sup> Serbia decreed general mobilisation on the 25th. Serbia accepted all of the terms of the ultimatum except for article six, which demanded that Austrian delegates be allowed in Serbia for the purpose of participation in the investigation into the assassination.<sup id="cite_ref-68" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-68">&#91;60&#93;</a></sup> Following this, Austria broke off diplomatic relations with Serbia and, the next day, ordered a partial mobilisation. Finally, on 28 July 1914, a month after the assassination, Austria-Hungary declared war on Serbia.\n</p>\n<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Austria_Hungary_ethnic.svg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/47/Austria_Hungary_ethnic.svg/220px-Austria_Hungary_ethnic.svg.png" width="220" height="170" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/47/Austria_Hungary_ethnic.svg/330px-Austria_Hungary_ethnic.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/47/Austria_Hungary_ethnic.svg/440px-Austria_Hungary_ethnic.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="1360" data-file-height="1052" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Austria_Hungary_ethnic.svg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Ethno-linguistic map of Austria-Hungary, 1910. <a href="/wiki/Austro-Hungarian_annexation_of_Bosnia_and_Herzegovina" class="mw-redirect" title="Austro-Hungarian annexation of Bosnia and Herzegovina">Bosnia-Herzegovina was annexed</a> in 1908.</div></div></div>\n<p>On 29 July, Russia, in support of Serbia, declared partial mobilisation against Austria-Hungary.<sup id="cite_ref-Levy_69-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Levy-69">&#91;61&#93;</a></sup> On the 30th, Russia ordered general mobilisation. German Chancellor <a href="/wiki/Theobald_von_Bethmann-Hollweg" title="Theobald von Bethmann-Hollweg">Theobald von Bethmann-Hollweg</a> waited until the 31st for an appropriate response, when Germany declared <i>Erkl\xc3\xa4rung des Kriegszustandes</i>, or "State of danger of war".<sup id="cite_ref-70" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-70">&#91;62&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-71" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-71">&#91;63&#93;</a></sup> Kaiser Wilhelm II asked his cousin, Tsar <a href="/wiki/Nicolas_II" class="mw-redirect" title="Nicolas II">Nicolas II</a>, to suspend the Russian general mobilisation. When he refused, Germany issued an ultimatum demanding its mobilisation be stopped, and a commitment not to support Serbia. Another was sent to France, asking her not to support Russia if it were to come to the defence of Serbia. On 1 August, after the Russian response, Germany mobilised and declared war on Russia. This also led to the general mobilisation in Austria-Hungary on 4 August.\n</p><p>The German government issued demands to France that it remain neutral as they had to decide which deployment plan to implement, it being difficult if not impossible to change the deployment whilst it was underway. The modified German <a href="/wiki/Schlieffen_Plan" title="Schlieffen Plan">Schlieffen Plan</a>, <i>Aufmarsch II West</i>, would deploy 80% of the army in the west, and <i>Aufmarsch I Ost</i> and <i>Aufmarsch II Ost</i> would deploy 60% in the west and 40% in the east as this was the maximum that the East Prussian railway infrastructure could carry. The French did not respond, but sent a mixed message by ordering their troops to withdraw 10&#160;km (6&#160;mi) from the border to avoid any incidents, and at the same time ordered the mobilisation of their reserves. Germany responded by mobilising its own reserves and implementing <i>Aufmarsch II West</i>.\n</p><p>On 1 August, Wilhelm ordered General <a href="/wiki/Helmuth_von_Moltke_the_Younger" title="Helmuth von Moltke the Younger">Helmuth von Moltke the Younger</a> to "march the whole of the \xe2\x80\xa6 army to the East" after being wrongly informed the British would remain neutral if France was not attacked. Moltke told the Kaiser that attempting to redeploy a million men was unthinkable, and that making it possible for the French to attack the Germans "in the rear" would prove disastrous. Yet Wilhelm insisted that the German army should not march into <a href="/wiki/Luxembourg" title="Luxembourg">Luxembourg</a> until he received a telegram sent by his cousin <a href="/wiki/George_V" title="George V">George V</a>, who made it clear that there had been a misunderstanding. Eventually the Kaiser told Moltke, "Now you can do what you want."<sup id="cite_ref-72" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-72">&#91;64&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-73" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-73">&#91;65&#93;</a></sup>  \n</p><p>On 2 August, Germany occupied Luxembourg, and on 3 August declared war on France; on the same day, they sent the Belgian government an ultimatum demanding unimpeded right of way through any part of Belgium, which was refused. Early on the morning of 4 August, the Germans invaded; <a href="/wiki/Albert_I_of_Belgium" title="Albert I of Belgium">King Albert</a> ordered his military to resist and called for assistance under the <a href="/wiki/Treaty_of_London_(1839)" title="Treaty of London (1839)">1839 Treaty of London</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTECrowe20014\xe2\x80\x935_74-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECrowe20014\xe2\x80\x935-74">&#91;66&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-75" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-75">&#91;67&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEWillmott200329_76-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWillmott200329-76">&#91;68&#93;</a></sup> Britain demanded Germany comply with the Treaty and respect Belgian neutrality; it declared war on Germany at 19:00&#160;UTC on 4 August 1914 (effective from 23:00), following an "unsatisfactory reply".<sup id="cite_ref-77" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-77">&#91;69&#93;</a></sup>\n</p>\n<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Progress_of_the_war">Progress of the war</span></h2>\n<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Further information: <a href="/wiki/Diplomatic_history_of_World_War_I" title="Diplomatic history of World War I">Diplomatic history of World War I</a></div>\n<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Opening_hostilities">Opening hostilities</span></h3>\n<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Confusion_among_the_Central_Powers">Confusion among the Central Powers</span></h4>\n<p>The strategy of the Central Powers suffered from miscommunication. Germany had promised to support Austria-Hungary\'s invasion of Serbia, but interpretations of what this meant differed. Previously tested deployment plans had been replaced early in 1914, but those had never been tested in exercises. Austro-Hungarian leaders believed Germany would cover its northern flank against Russia.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEStrachan2003292\xe2\x80\x93296,_343\xe2\x80\x93354_78-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEStrachan2003292\xe2\x80\x93296,_343\xe2\x80\x93354-78">&#91;70&#93;</a></sup> Germany, however, envisioned Austria-Hungary directing most of its troops against Russia, while Germany dealt with France. This confusion forced the <a href="/wiki/Austro-Hungarian_Army" title="Austro-Hungarian Army">Austro-Hungarian Army</a> to divide its forces between the Russian and Serbian fronts.\n</p>\n<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Serbian_campaign">Serbian campaign</span></h4>\n<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Serbian_Campaign_of_World_War_I" title="Serbian Campaign of World War I">Serbian Campaign of World War I</a></div>\n<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:FirstSerbianArmedPlane1915.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a6/FirstSerbianArmedPlane1915.jpg/220px-FirstSerbianArmedPlane1915.jpg" width="220" height="112" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a6/FirstSerbianArmedPlane1915.jpg/330px-FirstSerbianArmedPlane1915.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a6/FirstSerbianArmedPlane1915.jpg/440px-FirstSerbianArmedPlane1915.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1632" data-file-height="831" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:FirstSerbianArmedPlane1915.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Serbian Army <a href="/wiki/Bl%C3%A9riot_XI" title="Bl\xc3\xa9riot XI">Bl\xc3\xa9riot XI</a> "Oluj", 1915</div></div></div>\n<p>Austria invaded and fought the Serbian army at the <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Cer" title="Battle of Cer">Battle of Cer</a> and <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Kolubara" title="Battle of Kolubara">Battle of Kolubara</a> beginning on 12 August. Over the next two weeks, Austrian attacks were thrown back with heavy losses, which marked the first major Allied victories of the war and dashed Austro-Hungarian hopes of a swift victory. As a result, Austria had to keep sizeable forces on the Serbian front, weakening its efforts against Russia.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTETuckerRoberts2005172_79-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTETuckerRoberts2005172-79">&#91;71&#93;</a></sup> Serbia\'s defeat of the Austro-Hungarian invasion of 1914 has been called one of the major upset victories of the twentieth century.<sup id="cite_ref-80" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-80">&#91;72&#93;</a></sup>\n</p>\n<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="German_Offensive_in_Belgium_and_France">German Offensive in Belgium and France</span></h4>\n<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Western_Front_(World_War_I)" title="Western Front (World War I)">Western Front (World War I)</a></div>\n<p>When the war began, the <a href="/wiki/German_Army_order_of_battle_(1914)" title="German Army order of battle (1914)">German Order of Battle</a> placed 80% of the army in the West, with the remainder acting as a screening force in the East. The plan was to quickly knock France out of the war, then redeploy to the East and do the same to Russia. \n</p>\n<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:202px;"><a href="/wiki/File:German_soldiers_in_a_railroad_car_on_the_way_to_the_front_during_early_World_War_I,_taken_in_1914._Taken_from_greatwar.nl_site.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c0/German_soldiers_in_a_railroad_car_on_the_way_to_the_front_during_early_World_War_I%2C_taken_in_1914._Taken_from_greatwar.nl_site.jpg/200px-German_soldiers_in_a_railroad_car_on_the_way_to_the_front_during_early_World_War_I%2C_taken_in_1914._Taken_from_greatwar.nl_site.jpg" width="200" height="141" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c0/German_soldiers_in_a_railroad_car_on_the_way_to_the_front_during_early_World_War_I%2C_taken_in_1914._Taken_from_greatwar.nl_site.jpg/300px-German_soldiers_in_a_railroad_car_on_the_way_to_the_front_during_early_World_War_I%2C_taken_in_1914._Taken_from_greatwar.nl_site.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c0/German_soldiers_in_a_railroad_car_on_the_way_to_the_front_during_early_World_War_I%2C_taken_in_1914._Taken_from_greatwar.nl_site.jpg/400px-German_soldiers_in_a_railroad_car_on_the_way_to_the_front_during_early_World_War_I%2C_taken_in_1914._Taken_from_greatwar.nl_site.jpg 2x" data-file-width="650" data-file-height="459" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:German_soldiers_in_a_railroad_car_on_the_way_to_the_front_during_early_World_War_I,_taken_in_1914._Taken_from_greatwar.nl_site.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>German soldiers in a railway <a href="/wiki/Goods_wagon" title="Goods wagon">goods wagon</a> on the way to the front in 1914. Early in the war, all sides expected the conflict to be a short one.</div></div></div>\n<p>The German offensive in the West was officially titled <i>Aufmarsch I West,</i> but is better known as the <a href="/wiki/Schlieffen_Plan" title="Schlieffen Plan">Schlieffen Plan</a>, after its original creator. <a href="/wiki/Alfred_von_Schlieffen" title="Alfred von Schlieffen">Schlieffen</a> deliberately kept the left weak to lure the French into attacking across the Rhine, while the German right swept through Belgium, encircled Paris and trapped the French armies against the Swiss border; by charging into Alsace-Lorraine as envisaged by <a href="/wiki/Plan_XVII" title="Plan XVII">Plan XVII</a>, the French were actually helping that.<sup id="cite_ref-81" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-81">&#91;73&#93;</a></sup> However, his successor <a href="/wiki/Helmuth_von_Moltke_the_Younger" title="Helmuth von Moltke the Younger">Moltke</a> grew concerned by the danger of the French pushing too hard on his left flank and as the German Army increased in size, the allocation of forces between right and left wings changed from 85:15 to 70:30. Ultimately, Moltke\'s changes meant insufficient forces to achieve decisive success and thus unrealistic goals and timings.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHolmes2014194,_211_82-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHolmes2014194,_211-82">&#91;74&#93;</a></sup> It also assumed Russia could not mobilise quickly enough to force victory in the East, which again proved not to be the case.        \n</p>\n<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:202px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Georges_Scott,_A_la_ba%C3%AFonnette_!.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3c/Georges_Scott%2C_A_la_ba%C3%AFonnette_%21.jpg/200px-Georges_Scott%2C_A_la_ba%C3%AFonnette_%21.jpg" width="200" height="139" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3c/Georges_Scott%2C_A_la_ba%C3%AFonnette_%21.jpg/300px-Georges_Scott%2C_A_la_ba%C3%AFonnette_%21.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3c/Georges_Scott%2C_A_la_ba%C3%AFonnette_%21.jpg/400px-Georges_Scott%2C_A_la_ba%C3%AFonnette_%21.jpg 2x" data-file-width="891" data-file-height="621" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Georges_Scott,_A_la_ba%C3%AFonnette_!.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>French bayonet charge, <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_the_Frontiers" title="Battle of the Frontiers">Battle of the Frontiers</a>; by the end of August, French casualties exceeded 260,000, including 75,000 dead</div></div></div>\n<p>By the end of August, the Allied left, which included the <a href="/wiki/British_Expeditionary_Force_(World_War_I)" title="British Expeditionary Force (World War I)">British Expeditionary Force</a> or BEF was in full retreat; French casualties in the first month exceeded 260,000, including 27,000 killed on 22 August during the <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_the_Frontiers" title="Battle of the Frontiers">Battle of the Frontiers</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-83" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-83">&#91;75&#93;</a></sup> German planning provided broad strategic guidance, while allowing army commanders considerable freedom in carrying them out; this worked well in 1866 and 1870 but in 1914, <a href="/wiki/Alexander_von_Kluck" title="Alexander von Kluck">von Kluck</a> used this freedom to disobey orders, opening a gap between the German armies on the right.<sup id="cite_ref-84" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-84">&#91;76&#93;</a></sup> The French and British exploited this to halt the German advance east of Paris at the <a href="/wiki/First_Battle_of_the_Marne" title="First Battle of the Marne">First Battle of the Marne</a> from 5 to 12 September and push the German forces back some 50&#160;km (31&#160;mi).  \n</p><p>In 1911, the Russian <a href="/wiki/Stavka" title="Stavka">Stavka</a> had agreed with the French to attack Germany within 15 days of mobilisation, which was unrealistic and the two Russian armies that entered <a href="/wiki/East_Prussia" title="East Prussia">East Prussia</a> on 17 August did so without many of their support elements.<sup id="cite_ref-85" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-85">&#91;77&#93;</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/2nd_Army_(Russian_Empire)" title="2nd Army (Russian Empire)">Russian Second Army</a> was effectively destroyed at the <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Tannenberg" title="Battle of Tannenberg">Battle of Tannenberg</a> on 26-30 August but the Germans had been forced to re-route the <a href="/wiki/8th_Army_(German_Empire)" title="8th Army (German Empire)">8th Field Army</a> from France to East Prussia, a factor in Allied victory on the Marne. \n</p><p>By the end of 1914, German troops held strong defensive positions inside France, controlled the bulk of France\'s domestic coalfields and had inflicted 230,000 more casualties than it lost itself. However, communications problems and questionable command decisions cost Germany the chance of a decisive outcome while it had failed to achieve the primary objective of avoiding a long, two-front war.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTETuckerRoberts2005376\xe2\x80\x938_86-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTETuckerRoberts2005376\xe2\x80\x938-86">&#91;78&#93;</a></sup> This amounted to a strategic defeat; shortly after the Marne, <a href="/wiki/Wilhelm,_German_Crown_Prince" title="Wilhelm, German Crown Prince">Crown Prince Wilhelm</a> told an American reporter; \'We have lost the war. It will go on for a long time but lost it is already.\' <sup id="cite_ref-87" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-87">&#91;79&#93;</a></sup>\n</p>\n<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Asia_and_the_Pacific">Asia and the Pacific</span></h4>\n<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Asian_and_Pacific_theatre_of_World_War_I" title="Asian and Pacific theatre of World War I">Asian and Pacific theatre of World War I</a></div>\n<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Melbourne_recruiting_WWI.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bd/Melbourne_recruiting_WWI.jpg/220px-Melbourne_recruiting_WWI.jpg" width="220" height="158" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bd/Melbourne_recruiting_WWI.jpg/330px-Melbourne_recruiting_WWI.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bd/Melbourne_recruiting_WWI.jpg/440px-Melbourne_recruiting_WWI.jpg 2x" data-file-width="639" data-file-height="459" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Melbourne_recruiting_WWI.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Military_recruitment" title="Military recruitment">Military recruitment</a> in <a href="/wiki/Melbourne" title="Melbourne">Melbourne</a>, <a href="/wiki/Australia" title="Australia">Australia</a>, 1914</div></div></div>\n<p>New Zealand <a href="/wiki/Occupation_of_German_Samoa" title="Occupation of German Samoa">occupied</a> <a href="/wiki/German_Samoa" title="German Samoa">German Samoa</a> (later Western Samoa) on 30 August 1914.
