data-file-height="3080" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Sacrario_militare_di_Redipuglia_agosto_2014.JPG" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The Italian <a href="/wiki/Sacrario_militare_di_Redipuglia" title="Sacrario militare di Redipuglia">War Memorial of Redipuglia</a>, which contains the remains of 100,187 soldiers</div></div></div>\n<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:VERDUN-OSSUAIRE_DE_DOUAUMONT5.JPG" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fe/VERDUN-OSSUAIRE_DE_DOUAUMONT5.JPG/220px-VERDUN-OSSUAIRE_DE_DOUAUMONT5.JPG" width="220" height="145" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fe/VERDUN-OSSUAIRE_DE_DOUAUMONT5.JPG/330px-VERDUN-OSSUAIRE_DE_DOUAUMONT5.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fe/VERDUN-OSSUAIRE_DE_DOUAUMONT5.JPG/440px-VERDUN-OSSUAIRE_DE_DOUAUMONT5.JPG 2x" data-file-width="890" data-file-height="586" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:VERDUN-OSSUAIRE_DE_DOUAUMONT5.JPG" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The French military cemetery at the <a href="/wiki/Douaumont_ossuary" class="mw-redirect" title="Douaumont ossuary">Douaumont ossuary</a>, which contains the remains of more than 130,000 unknown soldiers</div></div></div>\n<p>A formal state of war between the two sides persisted for another seven months, until the signing of the <a href="/wiki/Treaty_of_Versailles" title="Treaty of Versailles">Treaty of Versailles</a> with Germany on 28 June 1919. The United States Senate did not ratify the treaty despite public support for it,<sup id="cite_ref-234" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-234">&#91;226&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-235" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-235">&#91;227&#93;</a></sup> and did not formally end its involvement in the war until the <a href="/wiki/Knox%E2%80%93Porter_Resolution" title="Knox\xe2\x80\x93Porter Resolution">Knox\xe2\x80\x93Porter Resolution</a> was signed on 2 July 1921 by President <a href="/wiki/Warren_G._Harding" title="Warren G. Harding">Warren G. Harding</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-236" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-236">&#91;228&#93;</a></sup> For the United Kingdom and the British Empire, the state of war ceased under the provisions of the <i><a href="/wiki/Termination_of_the_Present_War_(Definition)_Act_1918" title="Termination of the Present War (Definition) Act 1918">Termination of the Present War (Definition) Act 1918</a></i> with respect to:\n</p>\n<dl><dd><ul><li>Germany on 10 January 1920.<sup id="cite_ref-237" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-237">&#91;229&#93;</a></sup></li>\n<li>Austria on 16 July 1920.<sup id="cite_ref-238" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-238">&#91;230&#93;</a></sup></li>\n<li>Bulgaria on 9 August 1920.<sup id="cite_ref-239" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-239">&#91;231&#93;</a></sup></li>\n<li>Hungary on 26 July 1921.<sup id="cite_ref-240" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-240">&#91;232&#93;</a></sup></li>\n<li>Turkey on 6 August 1924.<sup id="cite_ref-241" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-241">&#91;233&#93;</a></sup></li></ul></dd></dl>\n<p>After the Treaty of Versailles, treaties with Austria, Hungary, Bulgaria, and the Ottoman Empire were signed. However, the negotiation of the treaty with the Ottoman Empire was followed by strife, and a final peace treaty between the Allied Powers and the country that would shortly become the <a href="/wiki/Republic_of_Turkey" class="mw-redirect" title="Republic of Turkey">Republic of Turkey</a> was not signed until 24 July 1923, at <a href="/wiki/Treaty_of_Lausanne" title="Treaty of Lausanne">Lausanne</a>.\n</p><p>Some <a href="/wiki/War_memorial" title="War memorial">war memorials</a> date the end of the war as being when the Versailles Treaty was signed in 1919, which was when many of the troops serving abroad finally returned home; by contrast, most commemorations of the war\'s end concentrate on the armistice of 11 November 1918. Legally, the formal peace treaties were not complete until the last, the Treaty of Lausanne, was signed. Under its terms, the Allied forces left <a href="/wiki/Istanbul" title="Istanbul">Constantinople</a> on 23 August 1923.\n</p>\n<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Peace_treaties_and_national_boundaries">Peace treaties and national boundaries</span></h3>\n<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Venizelos_signing_the_Treaty_of_Sevres.jpeg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/13/Venizelos_signing_the_Treaty_of_Sevres.jpeg/220px-Venizelos_signing_the_Treaty_of_Sevres.jpeg" width="220" height="160" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/13/Venizelos_signing_the_Treaty_of_Sevres.jpeg/330px-Venizelos_signing_the_Treaty_of_Sevres.jpeg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/13/Venizelos_signing_the_Treaty_of_Sevres.jpeg/440px-Venizelos_signing_the_Treaty_of_Sevres.jpeg 2x" data-file-width="704" data-file-height="512" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Venizelos_signing_the_Treaty_of_Sevres.jpeg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Greek prime minister <a href="/wiki/Eleftherios_Venizelos" title="Eleftherios Venizelos">Eleftherios Venizelos</a> signing the <a href="/wiki/Treaty_of_S%C3%A8vres" title="Treaty of S\xc3\xa8vres">Treaty of S\xc3\xa8vres</a></div></div></div>\n<p>After the war, the <a href="/wiki/Paris_Peace_Conference,_1919" title="Paris Peace Conference, 1919">Paris Peace Conference</a> imposed a series of peace treaties on the Central Powers officially ending the war. The 1919 Treaty of Versailles dealt with Germany and, building on <a href="/wiki/Fourteen_Points" title="Fourteen Points">Wilson\'s 14th point</a>, brought into being the <a href="/wiki/League_of_Nations" title="League of Nations">League of Nations</a> on 28 June 1919.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMagliveras19998\xe2\x80\x9312_242-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMagliveras19998\xe2\x80\x9312-242">&#91;234&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTENorthedge198635\xe2\x80\x9336_243-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTENorthedge198635\xe2\x80\x9336-243">&#91;235&#93;</a></sup>\n</p><p>The Central Powers had to acknowledge responsibility for "all the loss and damage to which the Allied and Associated Governments and their nationals have been subjected as a consequence of the war imposed upon them by" their aggression. In the Treaty of Versailles, this statement was <a href="/wiki/Article_231_of_the_Treaty_of_Versailles" title="Article 231 of the Treaty of Versailles">Article 231</a>. This article became known as the War Guilt clause as the majority of Germans felt humiliated and resentful.<sup id="cite_ref-244" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-244">&#91;236&#93;</a></sup> Overall the Germans felt they had been unjustly dealt with by what they called the "<a href="/wiki/Diktat" title="Diktat">diktat</a> of Versailles". German historian Hagen Schulze said the Treaty placed Germany "under legal sanctions, deprived of military power, economically ruined, and politically humiliated."<sup id="cite_ref-245" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-245">&#91;237&#93;</a></sup> Belgian historian Laurence Van Ypersele emphasises the central role played by memory of the war and the Versailles Treaty in German politics in the 1920s and 1930s:\n</p>\n<blockquote><p>Active denial of war guilt in Germany and German resentment at both reparations and continued Allied occupation of the Rhineland made widespread revision of the meaning and memory of the war problematic. The legend of the "<a href="/wiki/Stab_in_the_back" class="mw-redirect" title="Stab in the back">stab in the back</a>" and the wish to revise the "Versailles diktat", and the belief in an international threat aimed at the elimination of the German nation persisted at the heart of German politics. Even a man of peace such as [<a href="/wiki/Gustav_Stresemann" title="Gustav Stresemann">Gustav</a>] Stresemann publicly rejected German guilt. As for the Nazis, they waved the banners of domestic treason and international conspiracy in an attempt to galvanize the German nation into a spirit of revenge. Like a Fascist Italy, Nazi Germany sought to redirect the memory of the war to the benefit of its own policies.<sup id="cite_ref-246" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-246">&#91;238&#93;</a></sup></p></blockquote>\n<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:William_Orpen_-_The_Signing_of_Peace_in_the_Hall_of_Mirrors.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bc/William_Orpen_-_The_Signing_of_Peace_in_the_Hall_of_Mirrors.jpg/220px-William_Orpen_-_The_Signing_of_Peace_in_the_Hall_of_Mirrors.jpg" width="220" height="263" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bc/William_Orpen_-_The_Signing_of_Peace_in_the_Hall_of_Mirrors.jpg/330px-William_Orpen_-_The_Signing_of_Peace_in_the_Hall_of_Mirrors.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bc/William_Orpen_-_The_Signing_of_Peace_in_the_Hall_of_Mirrors.jpg/440px-William_Orpen_-_The_Signing_of_Peace_in_the_Hall_of_Mirrors.jpg 2x" data-file-width="2271" data-file-height="2720" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:William_Orpen_-_The_Signing_of_Peace_in_the_Hall_of_Mirrors.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The signing of the <a href="/wiki/Treaty_of_Versailles" title="Treaty of Versailles">Treaty of Versailles</a> in the <a href="/wiki/Hall_of_Mirrors" title="Hall of Mirrors">Hall of Mirrors</a>, Versailles, 28 June 1919</div></div></div>\n<p>Meanwhile, new nations liberated from German rule viewed the treaty as recognition of wrongs committed against small nations by much larger aggressive neighbours.<sup id="cite_ref-247" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-247">&#91;239&#93;</a></sup> The Peace Conference required all the defeated powers to pay <a href="/wiki/World_War_I_reparations" title="World War I reparations">reparations</a> for all the damage done to civilians. However, owing to economic difficulties and Germany being the only defeated power with an intact economy, the burden fell largely on Germany.\n</p><p>Austria-Hungary was partitioned into several successor states, including Austria, Hungary, Czechoslovakia, and <a href="/wiki/Yugoslavia" title="Yugoslavia">Yugoslavia</a>, largely but not entirely along ethnic lines. Transylvania was shifted from Hungary to <a href="/wiki/Greater_Romania" title="Greater Romania">Greater Romania</a>. The details were contained in the <a href="/wiki/Treaty_of_Saint-Germain" class="mw-redirect" title="Treaty of Saint-Germain">Treaty of Saint-Germain</a> and the Treaty of Trianon. As a result of the <a href="/wiki/Treaty_of_Trianon" title="Treaty of Trianon">Treaty of Trianon</a>, 3.3 million Hungarians came under foreign rule. Although the Hungarians made up 54% of the population of the pre-war <a href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_Hungary" title="Kingdom of Hungary">Kingdom of Hungary</a>, only 32% of its territory was left to Hungary. Between 1920 and 1924, 354,000 Hungarians fled former Hungarian territories attached to Romania, Czechoslovakia, and Yugoslavia.<sup id="cite_ref-248" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-248">&#91;240&#93;</a></sup>\n</p><p>The Russian Empire, which had withdrawn from the war in 1917 after the October Revolution, lost much of its western frontier as the newly independent nations of <a href="/wiki/History_of_Estonia#Road_to_the_republic" title="History of Estonia">Estonia</a>, <a href="/wiki/History_of_Finland#Independence_and_Civil_War" title="History of Finland">Finland</a>, <a href="/wiki/History_of_Latvia#Independence" title="History of Latvia">Latvia</a>, <a href="/wiki/History_of_Lithuania#Independent_Lithuania_(1918\xe2\x80\x9340)" title="History of Lithuania">Lithuania</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Second_Polish_Republic" title="Second Polish Republic">Poland</a> were carved from it. Romania took control of Bessarabia in April 1918.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEClark1927_249-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEClark1927-249">&#91;241&#93;</a></sup>\n</p><p>The Ottoman Empire disintegrated, with much of its <a href="/wiki/Levant" title="Levant">Levant</a> territory awarded to various Allied powers as protectorates. The Turkish core in <a href="/wiki/Anatolia" title="Anatolia">Anatolia</a> was reorganised as the Republic of Turkey. The Ottoman Empire was to be partitioned by the <a href="/wiki/Treaty_of_S%C3%A8vres" title="Treaty of S\xc3\xa8vres">Treaty of S\xc3\xa8vres</a> of 1920. This treaty was never ratified by the Sultan and was rejected by the <a href="/wiki/Turkish_National_Movement" title="Turkish National Movement">Turkish National Movement</a>, leading to the victorious <a href="/wiki/Turkish_War_of_Independence" title="Turkish War of Independence">Turkish War of Independence</a> and the much less stringent 1923 Treaty of Lausanne.\n</p>\n<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="National_identities">National identities</span></h3>\n<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Further information: <a href="/wiki/Sykes%E2%80%93Picot_Agreement" title="Sykes\xe2\x80\x93Picot Agreement">Sykes\xe2\x80\x93Picot Agreement</a></div>\n<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Map_Europe_1923-en.svg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/41/Map_Europe_1923-en.svg/220px-Map_Europe_1923-en.svg.png" width="220" height="149" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/41/Map_Europe_1923-en.svg/330px-Map_Europe_1923-en.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/41/Map_Europe_1923-en.svg/440px-Map_Europe_1923-en.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="1037" data-file-height="704" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Map_Europe_1923-en.svg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Map of territorial changes in Europe after World War I (as of 1923)</div></div></div>\n<p>Poland re-emerged as an independent country, after more than a century. The <a href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_Serbia" title="Kingdom of Serbia">Kingdom of Serbia</a> and its dynasty, as a "minor Entente nation" and the country with the most casualties per capita,<sup id="cite_ref-250" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-250">&#91;242&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-251" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-251">&#91;243&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-252" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-252">&#91;244&#93;</a></sup> became the backbone of a new multinational state, the <a href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_Serbs,_Croats_and_Slovenes" class="mw-redirect" title="Kingdom of Serbs, Croats and Slovenes">Kingdom of Serbs, Croats and Slovenes</a>, later renamed Yugoslavia. Czechoslovakia, combining the <a href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_Bohemia" title="Kingdom of Bohemia">Kingdom of Bohemia</a> with parts of the <a href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_Hungary" title="Kingdom of Hungary">Kingdom of Hungary</a>, became a new nation. Russia became the <a href="/wiki/Soviet_Union" title="Soviet Union">Soviet Union</a> and lost Finland, Estonia, Lithuania, and Latvia, which became independent countries. The <a href="/wiki/Ottoman_Empire" title="Ottoman Empire">Ottoman Empire</a> was soon replaced by Turkey and several other countries in the Middle East.\n</p><p>In the British Empire, the war unleashed new forms of nationalism. In Australia and New Zealand the <a href="/wiki/Gallipoli_Campaign" title="Gallipoli Campaign">Battle of Gallipoli</a> became known as those nations\' "Baptism of Fire". It was the first major war in which the newly established countries fought, and it was one of the first times that Australian troops fought as Australians, not just subjects of the <a href="/wiki/British_Crown" class="mw-redirect" title="British Crown">British Crown</a>. <a href="/wiki/Anzac_Day" title="Anzac Day">Anzac Day</a>, commemorating the <a href="/wiki/Australian_and_New_Zealand_Army_Corps" title="Australian and New Zealand Army Corps">Australian and New Zealand Army Corps</a>, celebrates this defining moment.<sup id="cite_ref-253" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-253">&#91;245&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-awmtradition_254-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-awmtradition-254">&#91;246&#93;</a></sup>\n</p><p>After the <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Vimy_Ridge" title="Battle of Vimy Ridge">Battle of Vimy Ridge</a>, where the Canadian divisions fought together for the first time as a single corps, Canadians began to refer to their country as a nation "forged from fire".<sup id="cite_ref-255" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-255">&#91;247&#93;</a></sup> Having succeeded on the same battleground where the "mother countries" had previously faltered, they were for the first time respected internationally for their own accomplishments. Canada entered the war as a <a href="/wiki/Dominion" title="Dominion">Dominion</a> of the British Empire and remained so, although it emerged with a greater measure of independence.<sup id="cite_ref-256" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-256">&#91;248&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-257" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-257">&#91;249&#93;</a></sup> When Britain declared war in 1914, the dominions were automatically at war; at the conclusion, Canada, Australia, New Zealand, and South Africa were individual signatories of the <a href="/wiki/Treaty_of_Versailles" title="Treaty of Versailles">Treaty of Versailles</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-258" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-258">&#91;250&#93;</a></sup>\n</p><p>Lobbying by <a href="/wiki/Chaim_Weizmann" title="Chaim Weizmann">Chaim Weizmann</a> and fear that American Jews would encourage the United States to support Germany culminated in the British government\'s <a href="/wiki/Balfour_Declaration" title="Balfour Declaration">Balfour Declaration</a> of 1917, endorsing creation of a <a href="/wiki/Jewish_homeland" class="mw-redirect" title="Jewish homeland">Jewish homeland</a> in Palestine.<sup id="cite_ref-259" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-259">&#91;251&#93;</a></sup> A total of more than 1,172,000 Jewish soldiers served in the Allied and Central Power forces in World War I, including 275,000 in Austria-Hungary and 450,000 in Tsarist Russia.<sup id="cite_ref-260" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-260">&#91;252&#93;</a></sup>\n</p><p>The establishment of the modern state of Israel and the roots of the continuing <a href="/wiki/Israeli%E2%80%93Palestinian_conflict" title="Israeli\xe2\x80\x93Palestinian conflict">Israeli\xe2\x80\x93Palestinian conflict</a> are partially found in the unstable power dynamics of the Middle East that resulted from World War I.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDoughty2005_261-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDoughty2005-261">&#91;253&#93;</a></sup> Before the end of the war, the <a href="/wiki/Ottoman_Empire" title="Ottoman Empire">Ottoman Empire</a> had maintained a modest level of peace and stability throughout the Middle East.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHooker1996_262-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHooker1996-262">&#91;254&#93;</a></sup> With the fall of the Ottoman government, power vacuums developed and conflicting claims to land and nationhood began to emerge.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMuller2008_263-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMuller2008-263">&#91;255&#93;</a></sup> The political boundaries drawn by the victors of World War I were quickly imposed, sometimes after only cursory consultation with the local population. These continue to be problematic in the 21st-century struggles for <a href="/wiki/National_identity" title="National identity">national identity</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKaplan1993_264-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKaplan1993-264">&#91;256&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESalibi1993_265-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESalibi1993-265">&#91;257&#93;</a></sup> While the dissolution of the <a href="/wiki/Ottoman_Empire" title="Ottoman Empire">Ottoman Empire</a> at the end of World War I was pivotal in contributing to the modern political situation of the Middle East, including the <a href="/wiki/Arab%E2%80%93Israeli_conflict" title="Arab\xe2\x80\x93Israeli conflict">Arab-Israeli conflict</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-Evans_2005_266-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Evans_2005-266">&#91;258&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEIsraeli_Foreign_Ministry_267-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEIsraeli_Foreign_Ministry-267">&#91;259&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Gelvin_2005_268-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Gelvin_2005-268">&#91;260&#93;</a></sup> the end of Ottoman rule also spawned lesser known disputes over water and other natural resources.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEIsaacHosh1992_269-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEIsaacHosh1992-269">&#91;261&#93;</a></sup>\n</p>\n<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Health_effects">Health effects</span></h3>\n<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Transporting_Ottoman_injured_at_Sirkedji.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/48/Transporting_Ottoman_injured_at_Sirkedji.jpg/220px-Transporting_Ottoman_injured_at_Sirkedji.jpg" width="220" height="151" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/48/Transporting_Ottoman_injured_at_Sirkedji.jpg/330px-Transporting_Ottoman_injured_at_Sirkedji.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/48/Transporting_Ottoman_injured_at_Sirkedji.jpg/440px-Transporting_Ottoman_injured_at_Sirkedji.jpg 2x" data-file-width="912" data-file-height="624" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Transporting_Ottoman_injured_at_Sirkedji.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Transporting Ottoman wounded at <a href="/wiki/Sirkeci" title="Sirkeci">Sirkeci</a></div></div></div>\n<p>The war had profound consequences on the health of soldiers. Of the 60&#160;million European military personnel who were mobilised from 1914 to 1918, <a href="/wiki/World_War_I_casualties" title="World War I casualties">8&#160;million were killed</a>, 7&#160;million were permanently disabled, and 15&#160;million were seriously injured. Germany lost 15.1% of its active male population, Austria-Hungary lost 17.1%, and France lost 10.5%.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKitchen200022_270-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKitchen200022-270">&#91;262&#93;</a></sup> In Germany, civilian deaths were 474,000 higher than in peacetime, due in large part to food shortages and malnutrition that weakened resistance to disease.<sup id="cite_ref-271" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-271">&#91;263&#93;</a></sup> By the end of the war, starvation caused by famine had killed approximately 100,000&#160;people in Lebanon.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESaadi2009_272-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESaadi2009-272">&#91;264&#93;</a></sup> Between 5 and 10 million people died in the <a href="/wiki/Russian_famine_of_1921" class="mw-redirect" title="Russian famine of 1921">Russian famine of 1921</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-273" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-273">&#91;265&#93;</a></sup> By 1922, there were between 4.5 million and 7 million homeless children in Russia as a result of nearly a decade of devastation from World War I, the Russian Civil War, and the subsequent famine of 1920\xe2\x80\x931922.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBall199616,_211_274-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBall199616,_211-274">&#91;266&#93;</a></sup> Numerous anti-Soviet Russians fled the country after the Revolution; by the 1930s, the northern Chinese city of <a href="/wiki/Harbin" title="Harbin">Harbin</a> had 100,000&#160;Russians.<sup id="cite_ref-275" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-275">&#91;267&#93;</a></sup> Thousands more emigrated to France, England, and the United States.\n</p>\n<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Emergency_hospital_during_Influenza_epidemic,_Camp_Funston,_Kansas_-_NCP_1603.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/20/Emergency_hospital_during_Influenza_epidemic%2C_Camp_Funston%2C_Kansas_-_NCP_1603.jpg/220px-Emergency_hospital_during_Influenza_epidemic%2C_Camp_Funston%2C_Kansas_-_NCP_1603.jpg" width="220" height="166" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/20/Emergency_hospital_during_Influenza_epidemic%2C_Camp_Funston%2C_Kansas_-_NCP_1603.jpg/330px-Emergency_hospital_during_Influenza_epidemic%2C_Camp_Funston%2C_Kansas_-_NCP_1603.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/20/Emergency_hospital_during_Influenza_epidemic%2C_Camp_Funston%2C_Kansas_-_NCP_1603.jpg/440px-Emergency_hospital_during_Influenza_epidemic%2C_Camp_Funston%2C_Kansas_-_NCP_1603.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1024" data-file-height="772" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Emergency_hospital_during_Influenza_epidemic,_Camp_Funston,_Kansas_-_NCP_1603.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Emergency military hospital during the <a href="/wiki/Spanish_flu" title="Spanish flu">Spanish flu</a> pandemic, which killed about 675,000 people in the United States alone, Camp Funston, Kansas, 1918</div></div></div>\n<p>The Australian prime minister, <a href="/wiki/Billy_Hughes" title="Billy Hughes">Billy Hughes</a>, wrote to the British prime minister, <a href="/wiki/Lloyd_George" class="mw-redirect" title="Lloyd George">Lloyd George</a>, "You have assured us that you cannot get better terms. I much regret it, and hope even now that some way may be found of securing agreement for demanding reparation commensurate with the tremendous sacrifices made by the British Empire and her Allies." Australia received \xc2\xa35,571,720 war reparations, but the direct cost of the war to Australia had been \xc2\xa3376,993,052, and, by the mid-1930s, repatriation pensions, war gratuities, interest and sinking fund charges were \xc2\xa3831,280,947.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESouter2000354_276-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESouter2000354-276">&#91;268&#93;</a></sup> Of about 416,000 Australians who served, about 60,000 were killed and another 152,000 were wounded.<sup id="cite_ref-277" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-277">&#91;269&#93;</a></sup>\n</p><p>Diseases flourished in the chaotic wartime conditions. In 1914 alone, louse-borne <a href="/wiki/Epidemic_typhus" title="Epidemic typhus">epidemic typhus</a> killed 200,000 in Serbia.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTETschanz_278-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTETschanz-278">&#91;270&#93;</a></sup> From 1918 to 1922, Russia had about 25&#160;million infections and 3 million deaths from epidemic typhus.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEConlon_279-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEConlon-279">&#91;271&#93;</a></sup> In 1923, 13 million Russians contracted malaria, a sharp increase from the pre-war years.<sup id="cite_ref-280" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-280">&#91;272&#93;</a></sup> In addition, a major influenza epidemic spread around the world. Overall, the <a href="/wiki/1918_flu_pandemic" class="mw-redirect" title="1918 flu pandemic">1918 flu pandemic</a> killed at least 50 million people.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKnobler2005_281-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKnobler2005-281">&#91;273&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-282" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-282">&#91;274&#93;</a></sup>\n</p><p>The social disruption and widespread violence of the Russian Revolution of 1917 and the ensuing <a href="/wiki/Russian_Civil_War" title="Russian Civil War">Russian Civil War</a> sparked more than 2,000 <a href="/wiki/Pogrom" title="Pogrom">pogroms</a> in the former Russian Empire, mostly in <a href="/wiki/Ukraine_after_the_Russian_Revolution" title="Ukraine after the Russian Revolution">Ukraine</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-283" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-283">&#91;275&#93;</a></sup> An estimated 60,000\xe2\x80\x93200,000&#160;civilian Jews were killed in the atrocities.<sup id="cite_ref-284" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-284">&#91;276&#93;</a></sup>\n</p><p>In the aftermath of World War I, Greece <a href="/wiki/Greco-Turkish_War_(1919%E2%80%931922)" title="Greco-Turkish War (1919\xe2\x80\x931922)">fought</a> against Turkish nationalists led by <a href="/wiki/Mustafa_Kemal_Atat%C3%BCrk" title="Mustafa Kemal Atat\xc3\xbcrk">Mustafa Kemal</a>, a war that eventually resulted in a <a href="/wiki/Population_exchange_between_Greece_and_Turkey" title="Population exchange between Greece and Turkey">massive population exchange between the two countries</a> under the <a href="/wiki/Treaty_of_Lausanne" title="Treaty of Lausanne">Treaty of Lausanne</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-285" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-285">&#91;277&#93;</a></sup> According to various sources,<sup id="cite_ref-286" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-286">&#91;278&#93;</a></sup> several hundred thousand Greeks died during this period, which was tied in with the <a href="/wiki/Greek_Genocide" class="mw-redirect" title="Greek Genocide">Greek Genocide</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-287" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-287">&#91;279&#93;</a></sup>\n</p>\n<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Technology">Technology</span></h2>\n<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">See also: <a href="/wiki/Technology_during_World_War_I" title="Technology during World War I">Technology during World War I</a> and <a href="/wiki/Weapons_of_World_War_I" class="mw-redirect" title="Weapons of World War I">Weapons of World War I</a></div>\n<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Ground_warfare">Ground warfare</span></h3>\n<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">See also: <a href="/wiki/Tanks_in_World_War_I" title="Tanks in World War I">Tanks in World War I</a></div>\n<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Tanks_on_parade_in_London_at_the_end_of_World_War_I,_1918_(3056450509).jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/32/Tanks_on_parade_in_London_at_the_end_of_World_War_I%2C_1918_%283056450509%29.jpg/220px-Tanks_on_parade_in_London_at_the_end_of_World_War_I%2C_1918_%283056450509%29.jpg" width="220" height="176" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/32/Tanks_on_parade_in_London_at_the_end_of_World_War_I%2C_1918_%283056450509%29.jpg/330px-Tanks_on_parade_in_London_at_the_end_of_World_War_I%2C_1918_%283056450509%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/32/Tanks_on_parade_in_London_at_the_end_of_World_War_I%2C_1918_%283056450509%29.jpg/440px-Tanks_on_parade_in_London_at_the_end_of_World_War_I%2C_1918_%283056450509%29.jpg 2x" data-file-width="4702" data-file-height="3755" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Tanks_on_parade_in_London_at_the_end_of_World_War_I,_1918_(3056450509).jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Tanks on parade in London at the end of World War I</div></div></div>\n<p>World War I began as a clash of 20th-century technology and 19th-century <a href="/wiki/Military_tactics" title="Military tactics">tactics</a>, with the inevitably large ensuing casualties. By the end of 1917, however, the major armies, now numbering millions of men, had modernised and were making use of telephone, <a href="/wiki/Wireless" title="Wireless">wireless communication</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHartcup1988154_288-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHartcup1988154-288">&#91;280&#93;</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Armored_car_(military)" title="Armored car (military)">armoured cars</a>, <a href="/wiki/Tank" title="Tank">tanks</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHartcup198882\xe2\x80\x9386_289-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHartcup198882\xe2\x80\x9386-289">&#91;281&#93;</a></sup> and aircraft. Infantry formations were reorganised, so that 100-man companies were no longer the main unit of manoeuvre; instead, squads of 10 or so men, under the command of a junior NCO, were favoured.\n</p><p>Artillery also underwent a revolution. In 1914, cannons were positioned in the front line and fired directly at their targets. By 1917, <a href="/wiki/Indirect_fire" title="Indirect fire">indirect fire</a> with guns (as well as mortars and even machine guns) was commonplace, using new techniques for spotting and ranging, notably aircraft and the often overlooked <a href="/wiki/Field_telephone" title="Field telephone">field telephone</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-290" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-290">&#91;282&#93;</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Counter-battery_fire" title="Counter-battery fire">Counter-battery</a> missions became commonplace, also, and sound detection was used to locate enemy batteries.\n</p>\n<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Austin21.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c7/Austin21.jpg/220px-Austin21.jpg" width="220" height="134" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c7/Austin21.jpg/330px-Austin21.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c7/Austin21.jpg/440px-Austin21.jpg 2x" data-file-width="800" data-file-height="488" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Austin21.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>A Russian armoured car, 1919</div></div></div>\n<p>Germany was far ahead of the Allies in using heavy indirect fire. The German Army employed 150&#160;mm (6&#160;in) and 210&#160;mm (8&#160;in) <a href="/wiki/Howitzer" title="Howitzer">howitzers</a> in 1914, when typical French and British guns were only 75&#160;mm (3&#160;in) and 105&#160;mm (4&#160;in). The British had a 6-inch (152&#160;mm) howitzer, but it was so heavy it had to be hauled to the field in pieces and assembled. The Germans also fielded Austrian 305&#160;mm (12&#160;in) and 420&#160;mm (17&#160;in) guns and, even at the beginning of the war, had inventories of various calibres of <i><a href="/wiki/Minenwerfer" title="Minenwerfer">Minenwerfer</a></i>, which were ideally suited for trench warfare.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMosier200142\xe2\x80\x9348_291-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMosier200142\xe2\x80\x9348-291">&#91;283&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-292" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-292">&#91;284&#93;</a></sup>\n</p>\n<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:38cmBttrPommern.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d9/38cmBttrPommern.jpg/220px-38cmBttrPommern.jpg" width="220" height="154" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d9/38cmBttrPommern.jpg/330px-38cmBttrPommern.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d9/38cmBttrPommern.jpg/440px-38cmBttrPommern.jpg 2x" data-file-width="614" data-file-height="429" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:38cmBttrPommern.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>38-cm "<a href="/wiki/Batterie_Pommern" title="Batterie Pommern">Lange Max</a>" of <a href="/wiki/Koekelare" title="Koekelare">Koekelare</a> (Leugenboom), biggest gun in the world in 1917</div></div></div>\n<p>On 27 June 1917 the Germans used the biggest gun in the world, <a href="/wiki/Batterie_Pommern" title="Batterie Pommern">Batterie Pommern</a>, nicknamed "<a href="/wiki/Lange_Max_Museum" title="Lange Max Museum">Lange Max</a>". This gun from <a href="/wiki/Krupp" title="Krupp">Krupp</a> was able to shoot 750&#160;kg shells from <a href="/wiki/Koekelare" title="Koekelare">Koekelare</a> to <a href="/wiki/Dunkirk" title="Dunkirk">Dunkirk</a>, a distance of about 50&#160;km (31&#160;mi).\n</p><p>Much of the combat involved <a href="/wiki/Trench_warfare" title="Trench warfare">trench warfare</a>, in which hundreds often died for each metre gained. Many of the deadliest battles in history occurred during World War I. Such battles include <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Passchendaele" title="Battle of Passchendaele">Ypres</a>, the <a href="/wiki/First_Battle_of_the_Marne" title="First Battle of the Marne">Marne</a>, <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Cambrai_(1917)" title="Battle of Cambrai (1917)">Cambrai</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_the_Somme" title="Battle of the Somme">Somme</a>, <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Verdun" title="Battle of Verdun">Verdun</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Gallipoli_Campaign" title="Gallipoli Campaign">Gallipoli</a>. The Germans employed the <a href="/wiki/Haber_process" title="Haber process">Haber process</a> of <a href="/wiki/Nitrogen_fixation" title="Nitrogen fixation">nitrogen fixation</a> to provide their forces with a constant supply of gunpowder despite the British naval blockade.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHartcup1988_293-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHartcup1988-293">&#91;285&#93;</a></sup> Artillery was responsible for the largest number of casualties<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTERaudzens1990421_294-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTERaudzens1990421-294">&#91;286&#93;</a></sup> and consumed vast quantities of explosives. The large number of head wounds caused by exploding shells and <a href="/wiki/Fragmentation_(weaponry)" title="Fragmentation (weaponry)">fragmentation</a> forced the combatant nations to develop the modern steel helmet, led by the French, who introduced the <a href="/wiki/Adrian_helmet" title="Adrian helmet">Adrian helmet</a> in 1915. It was quickly followed by the <a href="/wiki/Brodie_helmet" title="Brodie helmet">Brodie helmet</a>, worn by British Imperial and US troops, and in 1916 by the distinctive German <i><a href="/wiki/Stahlhelm" title="Stahlhelm">Stahlhelm</a></i>, a design, with improvements, still in use today.\n</p>\n<style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r856303468">.mw-parser-output .templatequote{overflow:hidden;margin:1em 0;padding:0 40px}.mw-parser-output .templatequote .templatequotecite{line-height:1.5em;text-align:left;padding-left:1.6em;margin-top:0}</style><blockquote class="templatequote">\n<div class="poem">\n<p>Gas! GAS! Quick, boys! \xe2\x80\x93 An ecstasy of fumbling,<br />\nFitting the clumsy helmets just in time;<br />\nBut someone still was yelling out and stumbling,<br />\nAnd flound\'ring like a man in fire or lime&#160;...<br />\nDim, through the misty panes and thick green light,<br />\nAs under a green sea, I saw him drowning.\n</p>\n</div><div class="templatequotecite">\xe2\x80\x94&#8201;<cite><a href="/wiki/Wilfred_Owen" title="Wilfred Owen">Wilfred Owen</a>, <i><a href="/wiki/Dulce_et_Decorum_est" title="Dulce et Decorum est">Dulce et Decorum est</a></i>, 1917<sup id="cite_ref-Wilfred_Owen_2004_295-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Wilfred_Owen_2004-295">&#91;287&#93;</a></sup></cite></div>\n</blockquote>\n<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Mustard_gas_burns.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/68/Mustard_gas_burns.jpg/220px-Mustard_gas_burns.jpg" width="220" height="157" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/68/Mustard_gas_burns.jpg/330px-Mustard_gas_burns.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/68/Mustard_gas_burns.jpg/440px-Mustard_gas_burns.jpg 2x" data-file-width="640" data-file-height="457" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Mustard_gas_burns.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>A Canadian soldier with <a href="/wiki/Mustard_gas" class="mw-redirect" title="Mustard gas">mustard gas</a> burns, c. 1917\xe2\x80\x931918</div></div></div>\n<p>The widespread use of chemical warfare was a distinguishing feature of the conflict. Gases used included <a href="/wiki/Chlorine" title="Chlorine">chlorine</a>, <a href="/wiki/Mustard_gas" class="mw-redirect" title="Mustard gas">mustard gas</a> and <a href="/wiki/Phosgene" title="Phosgene">phosgene</a>. Relatively few war casualties were caused by gas,<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTERaudzens1990_296-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTERaudzens1990-296">&#91;288&#93;</a></sup> as effective countermeasures to gas attacks were quickly created, such as <a href="/wiki/Gas_mask" title="Gas mask">gas masks</a>. The use of <a href="/wiki/Chemical_warfare" title="Chemical warfare">chemical warfare</a> and small-scale <a href="/wiki/Aerial_bombing_of_cities" title="Aerial bombing of cities">strategic bombing</a> were both outlawed by the <a href="/wiki/Hague_Conventions_of_1899_and_1907" title="Hague Conventions of 1899 and 1907">Hague Conventions of 1899 and 1907</a>, and both proved to be of limited effectiveness,<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHeller1984_297-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHeller1984-297">&#91;289&#93;</a></sup> though they captured the public imagination.<sup id="cite_ref-298" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-298">&#91;290&#93;</a></sup>\n</p><p>The most powerful land-based weapons were <a href="/wiki/Railway_gun" title="Railway gun">railway guns</a>, weighing dozens of tons apiece.<sup id="cite_ref-299" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-299">&#91;291&#93;</a></sup> The German version were nicknamed <a href="/wiki/Big_Bertha_(howitzer)" title="Big Bertha (howitzer)">Big Berthas</a>, even though the namesake was not a railway gun. Germany developed the <a href="/wiki/Paris_Gun" title="Paris Gun">Paris Gun</a>, able to bombard Paris from over 100 kilometres (62&#160;mi), though shells were relatively light at 94&#160;kilograms (210&#160;lb).\n</p>\n<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Vickers_machine_gun_in_the_Battle_of_Passchendaele_-_September_1917.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/af/Vickers_machine_gun_in_the_Battle_of_Passchendaele_-_September_1917.jpg/220px-Vickers_machine_gun_in_the_Battle_of_Passchendaele_-_September_1917.jpg" width="220" height="159" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/af/Vickers_machine_gun_in_the_Battle_of_Passchendaele_-_September_1917.jpg/330px-Vickers_machine_gun_in_the_Battle_of_Passchendaele_-_September_1917.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/af/Vickers_machine_gun_in_the_Battle_of_Passchendaele_-_September_1917.jpg/440px-Vickers_machine_gun_in_the_Battle_of_Passchendaele_-_September_1917.jpg 2x" data-file-width="3433" data-file-height="2480" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Vickers_machine_gun_in_the_Battle_of_Passchendaele_-_September_1917.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>British <a href="/wiki/Vickers_machine_gun" title="Vickers machine gun">Vickers machine gun</a>, 1917</div></div></div>\n<p>Trenches, machine guns, air reconnaissance, barbed wire, and modern artillery with fragmentation <a href="/wiki/Shell_(projectile)" title="Shell (projectile)">shells</a> helped bring the battle lines of World War I to a stalemate. The British and the French sought a solution with the creation of the tank and <a href="/wiki/Mechanised_warfare" class="mw-redirect" title="Mechanised warfare">mechanised warfare</a>. The British <a href="/wiki/Mark_I_(tank)" class="mw-redirect" title="Mark I (tank)">first tanks</a> were used during the <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_the_Somme" title="Battle of the Somme">Battle of the Somme</a> on 15 September 1916. Mechanical reliability was an issue, but the experiment proved its worth. Within a year, the British were fielding tanks by the hundreds, and they showed their potential during the <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Cambrai_(1917)" title="Battle of Cambrai (1917)">Battle of Cambrai</a> in November 1917, by breaking the Hindenburg Line, while <a href="/wiki/Combined_arms" title="Combined arms">combined arms</a> teams captured 8,000 enemy soldiers and 100&#160;guns. Meanwhile, the French introduced the first tanks with a rotating turret, the <a href="/wiki/Renault_FT" title="Renault FT">Renault FT</a>, which became a decisive tool of the victory. The conflict also saw the introduction of <a href="/wiki/Light_machine_gun" title="Light machine gun">light automatic weapons</a> and <a href="/wiki/Submachine_gun" title="Submachine gun">submachine guns</a>, such as the <a href="/wiki/Lewis_Gun" class="mw-redirect" title="Lewis Gun">Lewis Gun</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Browning_Automatic_Rifle" class="mw-redirect" title="Browning Automatic Rifle">Browning automatic rifle</a>, and the <a href="/wiki/Bergmann_MP18" class="mw-redirect" title="Bergmann MP18">Bergmann MP18</a>.\n</p><p>Another new weapon, the <a href="/wiki/Flamethrower" title="Flamethrower">flamethrower</a>, was first used by the German army and later adopted by other forces. Although not of high tactical value, the flamethrower was a powerful, demoralising weapon that caused terror on the battlefield.\n</p><p><a href="/wiki/Trench_railways" title="Trench railways">Trench railways</a> evolved to supply the enormous quantities of food, water, and ammunition required to support large numbers of soldiers in areas where conventional transportation systems had been destroyed. Internal combustion engines and improved traction systems for automobiles and trucks/lorries eventually rendered trench railways obsolete.\n</p>\n<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Areas_taken_in_major_attacks">Areas taken in major attacks</span></h4>\n<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:882px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Attack_areas_in_WW1.jpg" class="image"><img alt="Attack areas in WW1.jpg" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/cb/Attack_areas_in_WW1.jpg/880px-Attack_areas_in_WW1.jpg" width="880" height="406" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/c/cb/Attack_areas_in_WW1.jpg 1.5x" data-file-width="1300" data-file-height="600" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Attack_areas_in_WW1.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div></div></div></div>\n<p>On the Western Front neither side made impressive gains in the first three years of the war with attacks at <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Verdun" title="Battle of Verdun">Verdun</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_the_Somme" title="Battle of the Somme">Somme</a>, <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Passchendaele" title="Battle of Passchendaele">Passchendaele</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Cambrai_(1917)" title="Battle of Cambrai (1917)">Cambrai</a> \xe2\x80\x94 the exception was <a href="/wiki/Nivelle_Offensive" title="Nivelle Offensive">Nivelle\xe2\x80\x99s Offensive</a> in which the German defence gave ground while mauling the attackers so badly that there were mutinies in the French Army. In 1918 the Germans smashed through the defence lines in three great attacks: <a href="/wiki/Operation_Michael" title="Operation Michael">Michael</a>, on the <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_the_Lys_(1918)" title="Battle of the Lys (1918)">Lys</a>, and on the <a href="/wiki/Third_Battle_of_the_Aisne" title="Third Battle of the Aisne">Aisne</a>, which displayed the power of their new tactics. The Allies struck back at <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Soissons_(1918)" title="Battle of Soissons (1918)">Soissons</a>, which showed the Germans that they must return to the defensive, and at <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Amiens_(1918)" title="Battle of Amiens (1918)">Amiens</a>; tanks played a prominent role in both of these assaults, as they had the year before at Cambrai.\n</p><p>The areas in the East were larger. The Germans did well at the <a href="/wiki/First_Battle_of_the_Masurian_Lakes" title="First Battle of the Masurian Lakes">First Masurian Lakes</a> driving the invaders from East Prussia, and at <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Jugla" title="Battle of Jugla">Riga</a>, which led the Russians to sue for peace. The Austro-Hungarians and Germans joined for a great success at <a href="/wiki/Gorlice%E2%80%93Tarn%C3%B3w_Offensive" title="Gorlice\xe2\x80\x93Tarn\xc3\xb3w Offensive">Gorlice\xe2\x80\x93Tarn\xc3\xb3w</a>, which drove the Russians out of Poland. In a series of attacks along with the Bulgarians they occupied Serbia, Albania, Montenegro and most of Romania. The Allies successes came later in <a href="/wiki/Third_Battle_of_Gaza" title="Third Battle of Gaza">Palestine</a>, the beginning of the end for the Ottomans, in <a href="/wiki/Vardar_Offensive" title="Vardar Offensive">Macedonia</a>, which drove the Bulgarians out of the war, and at <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Vittorio_Veneto" title="Battle of Vittorio Veneto">Vittorio Veneto</a>, the final blow for the Austro-Hungarians. The area occupied in East by the Central powers on 11 November 1918 was 1,042,600&#160;km<sup>2</sup> (402,600&#160;sq&#160;mi).\n</p>\n<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Naval">Naval</span></h3>\n<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Bundesarchiv_DVM_10_Bild-23-61-15,_Panzerkreuzer_%22SMS_Goeben%22.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f7/Bundesarchiv_DVM_10_Bild-23-61-15%2C_Panzerkreuzer_%22SMS_Goeben%22.jpg/220px-Bundesarchiv_DVM_10_Bild-23-61-15%2C_Panzerkreuzer_%22SMS_Goeben%22.jpg" width="220" height="126" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f7/Bundesarchiv_DVM_10_Bild-23-61-15%2C_Panzerkreuzer_%22SMS_Goeben%22.jpg/330px-Bundesarchiv_DVM_10_Bild-23-61-15%2C_Panzerkreuzer_%22SMS_Goeben%22.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f7/Bundesarchiv_DVM_10_Bild-23-61-15%2C_Panzerkreuzer_%22SMS_Goeben%22.jpg/440px-Bundesarchiv_DVM_10_Bild-23-61-15%2C_Panzerkreuzer_%22SMS_Goeben%22.jpg 2x" data-file-width="800" data-file-height="458" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Bundesarchiv_DVM_10_Bild-23-61-15,_Panzerkreuzer_%22SMS_Goeben%22.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The <a href="/wiki/Moltke-class_battlecruiser" title="Moltke-class battlecruiser"><i>Moltke</i>-class</a> <a href="/wiki/Ottoman_battlecruiser_Yav%C3%BBz_Sult%C3%A2n_Sel%C3%AEm" class="mw-redirect" title="Ottoman battlecruiser Yav\xc3\xbbz Sult\xc3\xa2n Sel\xc3\xaem">Ottoman battlecruiser&#160;<i>Yav\xc3\xbbz Sult\xc3\xa2n Sel\xc3\xaem</i></a></div></div></div>\n<p>Germany deployed <a href="/wiki/U-boat" title="U-boat">U-boats</a> (<a href="/wiki/Submarine" title="Submarine">submarines</a>) after the war began. Alternating between restricted and unrestricted submarine warfare in the Atlantic, the <a href="/wiki/Kaiserliche_Marine" class="mw-redirect" title="Kaiserliche Marine">Kaiserliche Marine</a> employed them to deprive the British Isles of vital supplies. The deaths of British merchant sailors and the seeming invulnerability of U-boats led to the development of depth charges (1916), <a href="/wiki/Hydrophone" title="Hydrophone">hydrophones</a> (passive <a href="/wiki/Sonar" title="Sonar">sonar</a>, 1917), <a href="/wiki/Blimp" title="Blimp">blimps</a>, <a href="/wiki/Hunter-killer_submarine" class="mw-redirect" title="Hunter-killer submarine">hunter-killer submarines</a> (<a href="/wiki/British_R-class_submarine" title="British R-class submarine">HMS <i>R-1</i></a>, 1917), forward-throwing <a href="/wiki/Anti-submarine_weapon" title="Anti-submarine weapon">anti-submarine weapons</a>, and dipping hydrophones (the latter two both abandoned in 1918).<sup id="cite_ref-price1980_130-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-price1980-130">&#91;122&#93;</a></sup> To extend their operations, the Germans proposed supply submarines (1916). Most of these would be forgotten in the <a href="/wiki/Interwar_period" title="Interwar period">interwar period</a> until World War II revived the need.<sup id="cite_ref-300" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-300">&#91;292&#93;</a></sup>\n</p>\n<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Aviation">Aviation</span></h3>\n<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Aviation_in_World_War_I" title="Aviation in World War I">Aviation in World War I</a></div>\n<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Sopwith_F-1_Camel.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/28/Sopwith_F-1_Camel.jpg/220px-Sopwith_F-1_Camel.jpg" width="220" height="134" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/28/Sopwith_F-1_Camel.jpg/330px-Sopwith_F-1_Camel.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/28/Sopwith_F-1_Camel.jpg/440px-Sopwith_F-1_Camel.jpg 2x" data-file-width="499" data-file-height="303" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Sopwith_F-1_Camel.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/RAF" class="mw-redirect" title="RAF">RAF</a> <a href="/wiki/Sopwith_Camel" title="Sopwith Camel">Sopwith Camel</a>. In April 1917, the average life expectancy of a British pilot on the Western Front was 93 flying hours.<sup id="cite_ref-301" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-301">&#91;293&#93;</a></sup></div></div></div>\n<p><a href="/wiki/Fixed-wing_aircraft" title="Fixed-wing aircraft">Fixed-wing aircraft</a> were first used militarily by the Italians in Libya on 23 October 1911 during the <a href="/wiki/Italo-Turkish_War" title="Italo-Turkish War">Italo-Turkish War</a> for reconnaissance, soon followed by the dropping of grenades and <a href="/wiki/Aerial_photography" title="Aerial photography">aerial photography</a> the next year. By 1914, their military utility was obvious. They were initially used for <a href="/wiki/Reconnaissance" title="Reconnaissance">reconnaissance</a> and <a href="/wiki/Close_air_support" title="Close air support">ground attack</a>. To shoot down enemy planes, <a href="/wiki/Anti-aircraft_guns" class="mw-redirect" title="Anti-aircraft guns">anti-aircraft guns</a> and <a href="/wiki/Fighter_aircraft" title="Fighter aircraft">fighter aircraft</a> were developed. <a href="/wiki/Strategic_bomber" title="Strategic bomber">Strategic bombers</a> were created, principally by the Germans and British, though the former used <a href="/wiki/Zeppelin" title="Zeppelin">Zeppelins</a> as well.<sup id="cite_ref-Cross_1991_302-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Cross_1991-302">&#91;294&#93;</a></sup> Towards the end of the conflict, <a href="/wiki/Aircraft_carrier" title="Aircraft carrier">aircraft carriers</a> were used for the first time, with <a href="/wiki/HMS_Furious_(47)" title="HMS Furious (47)">HMS&#160;<i>Furious</i></a> launching <a href="/wiki/Sopwith_Camels" class="mw-redirect" title="Sopwith Camels">Sopwith Camels</a> in <a href="/wiki/Tondern_raid" title="Tondern raid">a raid</a> to destroy the Zeppelin hangars at <a href="/wiki/Tondern" class="mw-redirect" title="Tondern">Tondern</a> in 1918.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTECross199156\xe2\x80\x9357_303-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECross199156\xe2\x80\x9357-303">&#91;295&#93;</a></sup>\n</p><p>Manned <a href="/wiki/Observation_balloon" title="Observation balloon">observation balloons</a>, floating high above the trenches, were used as stationary reconnaissance platforms, reporting enemy movements and directing artillery. Balloons commonly had a crew of two, equipped with <a href="/wiki/Parachute" title="Parachute">parachutes</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEWinter1983_304-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWinter1983-304">&#91;296&#93;</a></sup> so that if there was an enemy air attack the crew could parachute to safety. At the time, parachutes were too heavy to be used by pilots of aircraft (with their marginal power output), and smaller versions were not developed until the end of the war; they were also opposed by the British leadership, who feared they might promote cowardice.<sup id="cite_ref-FullCircle_305-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FullCircle-305">&#91;297&#93;</a></sup>\n</p><p>Recognised for their value as observation platforms, balloons were important targets for enemy aircraft. To defend them against air attack, they were heavily protected by antiaircraft guns and patrolled by friendly aircraft; to attack them, unusual weapons such as air-to-air rockets were tried. Thus, the reconnaissance value of blimps and balloons contributed to the development of air-to-air combat between all types of aircraft, and to the trench stalemate, because it was impossible to move large numbers of troops undetected. The Germans conducted air raids on England during 1915 and 1916 with airships, hoping to damage British morale and cause aircraft to be diverted from the front lines, and indeed the resulting panic led to the diversion of several squadrons of fighters from France.<sup id="cite_ref-Cross_1991_302-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Cross_1991-302">&#91;294&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FullCircle_305-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FullCircle-305">&#91;297&#93;</a></sup>\n</p>\n<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="War_crimes">War crimes</span></h2>\n<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Baralong_incidents">Baralong incidents</span></h3>\n<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Baralong_incidents" title="Baralong incidents">Baralong incidents</a></div>\n<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:HMS_Baralong.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fd/HMS_Baralong.jpg/220px-HMS_Baralong.jpg" width="220" height="112" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fd/HMS_Baralong.jpg/330px-HMS_Baralong.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fd/HMS_Baralong.jpg/440px-HMS_Baralong.jpg 2x" data-file-width="6456" data-file-height="3290" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:HMS_Baralong.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>HMS <i>Baralong</i></div></div></div>\n<p>On 19 August 1915, the German submarine <a href="/wiki/SM_U-27_(Germany)" title="SM U-27 (Germany)">U-27</a> was sunk by the British <a href="/wiki/Q-ship" title="Q-ship">Q-ship</a> <a href="/wiki/HMS_Baralong" title="HMS Baralong">HMS&#160;<i>Baralong</i></a>. All German survivors were <a href="/wiki/Summarily_executed" class="mw-redirect" title="Summarily executed">summarily executed</a> by <i>Baralong</i><span class="nowrap" style="padding-left:0.1em;">&#39;</span>s crew on the orders of Lieutenant <a href="/wiki/Godfrey_Herbert" title="Godfrey Herbert">Godfrey Herbert</a>, the captain of the ship. The shooting was reported to the media by American citizens who were on board the <i>Nicosia</i>, a British freighter loaded with war supplies, which was stopped by U-27 just minutes before the incident.<sup id="cite_ref-306" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-306">&#91;298&#93;</a></sup>\n</p><p>On 24 September, <i>Baralong</i> destroyed <a href="/wiki/SM_U-41_(Germany)" title="SM U-41 (Germany)">U-41</a>, which was in the process of sinking the cargo ship <i>Urbino</i>. According to Karl Goetz, the submarine\'s commander, <i>Baralong</i> continued to fly the US flag after firing on U-41 and then rammed the lifeboat \xe2\x80\x93 carrying the German survivors \xe2\x80\x93 sinking it.<sup id="cite_ref-307" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-307">&#91;299&#93;</a></sup>\n</p>\n<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Torpedoing_of_HMHS_Llandovery_Castle">Torpedoing of HMHS <i>Llandovery Castle</i></span></h3>\n<p>The Canadian hospital ship <a href="/wiki/HMHS_Llandovery_Castle" title="HMHS Llandovery Castle">HMHS&#160;<i>Llandovery Castle</i></a> was torpedoed by the German submarine <a href="/wiki/SM_U-86" title="SM U-86">SM U-86</a> on 27 June 1918 in violation of international law. Only 24 of the 258 medical personnel, patients, and crew survived. Survivors reported that the U-boat surfaced and ran down the lifeboats, machine-gunning survivors in the water. The U-boat captain, <a href="/wiki/Helmut_Patzig" class="mw-redirect" title="Helmut Patzig">Helmut Patzig</a>, was charged with war crimes in Germany following the war, but escaped prosecution by going to the <a href="/wiki/Free_City_of_Danzig" title="Free City of Danzig">Free City of Danzig</a>, beyond the jurisdiction of German courts.<sup id="cite_ref-Davies2013c_308-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Davies2013c-308">&#91;300&#93;</a></sup>\n</p>\n<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Chemical_weapons_in_warfare">Chemical weapons in warfare</span></h3>\n<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Chemical_weapons_in_World_War_I" title="Chemical weapons in World War I">Chemical weapons in World War I</a></div>\n<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:French_soldiers_making_a_gas_and_flame_attack_on_German_trenches_in_Flanders._Belgium.,_ca._1900_-_1982_-_NARA_-_530722.tif" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/da/French_soldiers_making_a_gas_and_flame_attack_on_German_trenches_in_Flanders._Belgium.%2C_ca._1900_-_1982_-_NARA_-_530722.tif/lossy-page1-220px-French_soldiers_making_a_gas_and_flame_attack_on_German_trenches_in_Flanders._Belgium.%2C_ca._1900_-_1982_-_NARA_-_530722.tif.jpg" width="220" height="189" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/da/French_soldiers_making_a_gas_and_flame_attack_on_German_trenches_in_Flanders._Belgium.%2C_ca._1900_-_1982_-_NARA_-_530722.tif/lossy-page1-330px-French_soldiers_making_a_gas_and_flame_attack_on_German_trenches_in_Flanders._Belgium.%2C_ca._1900_-_1982_-_NARA_-_530722.tif.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/da/French_soldiers_making_a_gas_and_flame_attack_on_German_trenches_in_Flanders._Belgium.%2C_ca._1900_-_1982_-_NARA_-_530722.tif/lossy-page1-440px-French_soldiers_making_a_gas_and_flame_attack_on_German_trenches_in_Flanders._Belgium.%2C_ca._1900_-_1982_-_NARA_-_530722.tif.jpg 2x" data-file-width="3000" data-file-height="2577" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:French_soldiers_making_a_gas_and_flame_attack_on_German_trenches_in_Flanders._Belgium.,_ca._1900_-_1982_-_NARA_-_530722.tif" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>French soldiers making a gas and flame attack on German trenches in Flanders</div></div></div>\n<p>The first successful use of <a href="/wiki/Chemical_warfare" title="Chemical warfare">poison gas</a> as a weapon of warfare occurred during the Second Battle of Ypres (22 April \xe2\x80\x93 25 May 1915).<sup id="cite_ref-309" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-309">&#91;301&#93;</a></sup> Gas was soon used by all major belligerents throughout the war. It is estimated that the use of chemical weapons employed by both sides throughout the war had inflicted 1.3 million casualties. For example, the British had over 180,000 chemical weapons casualties during the war, and up to one-third of American casualties were caused by them. The Russian Army reportedly suffered roughly 500,000 chemical weapon casualties in World War I.<sup id="cite_ref-310" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-310">&#91;302&#93;</a></sup> The use of chemical weapons in warfare was in direct violation of the <a href="/wiki/Hague_Conventions_of_1899_and_1907#Hague_Convention_of_1899" title="Hague Conventions of 1899 and 1907">1899 Hague Declaration Concerning Asphyxiating Gases</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Hague_Convention_of_1907" class="mw-redirect" title="Hague Convention of 1907">1907 Hague Convention on Land Warfare</a>, which prohibited their use.<sup id="cite_ref-311" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-311">&#91;303&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-312" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-312">&#91;304&#93;</a></sup>\n</p><p>The effect of poison gas was not limited to combatants. Civilians were at risk from the gases as winds blew the poison gases through their towns, and they rarely received warnings or alerts of potential danger. In addition to absent warning systems, civilians often did not have access to effective gas masks. An estimated 100,000\xe2\x80\x93260,000 civilian casualties were caused by chemical weapons during the conflict and tens of thousands more (along with military personnel) died from scarring of the lungs, skin damage, and cerebral damage in the years after the conflict ended. Many commanders on both sides knew such weapons would cause major harm to civilians but nonetheless continued to use them. British <a href="/wiki/Field_marshal_(United_Kingdom)" title="Field marshal (United Kingdom)">Field Marshal</a> <a href="/wiki/Sir_Douglas_Haig" class="mw-redirect" title="Sir Douglas Haig">Sir Douglas Haig</a> wrote in his diary, "My officers and I were aware that such weapons would cause harm to women and children living in nearby towns, as strong winds were common in the battlefront. However, because the weapon was to be directed against the enemy, none of us were overly concerned at all."<sup id="cite_ref-313" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-313">&#91;305&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-314" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-314">&#91;306&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-315" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-315">&#91;307&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-316" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-316">&#91;308&#93;</a></sup>\n</p>\n<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Genocide_and_ethnic_cleansing">Genocide and ethnic cleansing</span></h3>\n<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">See also: <a href="/wiki/Armenian_Genocide" title="Armenian Genocide">Armenian Genocide</a>, <a href="/wiki/Assyrian_genocide" title="Assyrian genocide">Assyrian genocide</a>, <a href="/wiki/Greek_genocide" title="Greek genocide">Greek genocide</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Genocide_denial" title="Genocide denial">Genocide denial</a></div>\n<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Morgenthau336.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1f/Morgenthau336.jpg/220px-Morgenthau336.jpg" width="220" height="150" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1f/Morgenthau336.jpg/330px-Morgenthau336.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1f/Morgenthau336.jpg/440px-Morgenthau336.jpg 2x" data-file-width="3999" data-file-height="2731" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Morgenthau336.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Armenians killed during the Armenian Genocide. Image taken from <i>Ambassador Morgenthau\'s Story</i>, written by <a href="/wiki/Henry_Morgenthau,_Sr." class="mw-redirect" title="Henry Morgenthau, Sr.">Henry Morgenthau, Sr.</a> and published in 1918.<sup id="cite_ref-317" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-317">&#91;309&#93;</a></sup></div></div></div>\n<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Hromadn%C3%A1_poprava_srbsk%C3%A9ho_obyvatelstva.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a2/Hromadn%C3%A1_poprava_srbsk%C3%A9ho_obyvatelstva.jpg/220px-Hromadn%C3%A1_poprava_srbsk%C3%A9ho_obyvatelstva.jpg" width="220" height="135" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a2/Hromadn%C3%A1_poprava_srbsk%C3%A9ho_obyvatelstva.jpg/330px-Hromadn%C3%A1_poprava_srbsk%C3%A9ho_obyvatelstva.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a2/Hromadn%C3%A1_poprava_srbsk%C3%A9ho_obyvatelstva.jpg/440px-Hromadn%C3%A1_poprava_srbsk%C3%A9ho_obyvatelstva.jpg 2x" data-file-width="600" data-file-height="368" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Hromadn%C3%A1_poprava_srbsk%C3%A9ho_obyvatelstva.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Austro-Hungarian soldiers executing men and women in Serbia, 1916<sup id="cite_ref-318" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-318">&#91;310&#93;</a></sup></div></div></div>\n<p>The <a href="/wiki/Ethnic_cleansing" title="Ethnic cleansing">ethnic cleansing</a> of the Ottoman Empire\'s <a href="/wiki/Armenians" title="Armenians">Armenian</a> population, including mass deportations and executions, during the final years of the Ottoman Empire is considered <a href="/wiki/Genocide" title="Genocide">genocide</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-IAGSletter_319-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-IAGSletter-319">&#91;311&#93;</a></sup> The Ottomans carried out organised and systematic massacres of the Armenian population at the beginning of the war and portrayed deliberately provoked acts of Armenian resistance as rebellions to justify further extermination.<sup id="cite_ref-leverkun_320-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-leverkun-320">&#91;312&#93;</a></sup> In early 1915, a number of Armenians volunteered to join the Russian forces and the Ottoman government used this as a pretext to issue the <a href="/wiki/Tehcir_Law" title="Tehcir Law">Tehcir Law</a> (Law on Deportation), which authorised the deportation of Armenians from the Empire\'s eastern provinces to Syria between 1915 and 1918. The Armenians were intentionally <a href="/wiki/Death_march" title="Death march">marched to death</a> and a number were attacked by Ottoman brigands.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFerguson2006177_321-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFerguson2006177-321">&#91;313&#93;</a></sup> While an exact number of deaths is unknown, the <a href="/wiki/International_Association_of_Genocide_Scholars" title="International Association of Genocide Scholars">International Association of Genocide Scholars</a> estimates 1.5 million.<sup id="cite_ref-IAGSletter_319-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-IAGSletter-319">&#91;311&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-322" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-322">&#91;314&#93;</a></sup> The government of Turkey has consistently <a href="/wiki/Armenian_Genocide_denial" title="Armenian Genocide denial">denied the genocide</a>, arguing that those who died were victims of inter-ethnic fighting, famine, or disease during World War I; these claims are rejected by most historians.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFromkin1989212\xe2\x80\x93215_323-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFromkin1989212\xe2\x80\x93215-323">&#91;315&#93;</a></sup> Other ethnic groups were similarly attacked by the Ottoman Empire during this period, including <a href="/wiki/Assyrian_Genocide" class="mw-redirect" title="Assyrian Genocide">Assyrians</a> and <a href="/wiki/Greek_genocide" title="Greek genocide">Greeks</a>, and some scholars consider those events to be part of the same policy of extermination.<sup id="cite_ref-324" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-324">&#91;316&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-325" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-325">&#91;317&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-326" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-326">&#91;318&#93;</a></sup>\n</p>\n<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Russian_Empire">Russian Empire</span></h4>\n<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Anti-Jewish_pogroms_in_the_Russian_Empire" title="Anti-Jewish pogroms in the Russian Empire">Anti-Jewish pogroms in the Russian Empire</a></div>\n<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">See also: <a href="/wiki/Russian_occupation_of_Eastern_Galicia,_1914%E2%80%931915" class="mw-redirect" title="Russian occupation of Eastern Galicia, 1914\xe2\x80\x931915">Russian occupation of Eastern Galicia, 1914\xe2\x80\x931915</a>; <a href="/wiki/Volhynia" title="Volhynia">Volhynia</a>; <a href="/wiki/Volga_Germans" title="Volga Germans">Volga Germans</a>; and <a href="/wiki/Urkun" class="mw-redirect" title="Urkun">Urkun</a></div>\n<p>Many <a href="/wiki/Pogrom" title="Pogrom">pogroms</a> accompanied the <a href="/wiki/Russian_Revolution" title="Russian Revolution">Russian Revolution</a> of 1917 and the ensuing <a href="/wiki/Russian_Civil_War" title="Russian Civil War">Russian Civil War</a>. 60,000\xe2\x80\x93200,000 civilian Jews were killed in the atrocities throughout the former Russian Empire (mostly within the <a href="/wiki/Pale_of_Settlement" title="Pale of Settlement">Pale of Settlement</a> in present-day <a href="/wiki/Ukraine" title="Ukraine">Ukraine</a>).<sup id="cite_ref-327" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-327">&#91;319&#93;</a></sup>\n</p>\n<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Rape_of_Belgium">Rape of Belgium</span></h3>\n<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Rape_of_Belgium" title="Rape of Belgium">Rape of Belgium</a></div>\n<p>The German invaders treated any resistance\xe2\x80\x94such as sabotaging rail lines\xe2\x80\x94as illegal and immoral, and shot the offenders and burned buildings in retaliation. In addition, they tended to suspect that most civilians were potential <i><a href="/wiki/Francs-tireurs" title="Francs-tireurs">francs-tireurs</a></i> (<a href="/wiki/Guerrillas" class="mw-redirect" title="Guerrillas">guerrillas</a>) and, accordingly, took and sometimes killed hostages from among the civilian population. The German army executed over 6,500 French and Belgian civilians between August and November 1914, usually in near-random large-scale shootings of civilians ordered by junior German officers. The German Army destroyed 15,000\xe2\x80\x9320,000 buildings\xe2\x80\x94most famously the university library at <a href="/wiki/Leuven" title="Leuven">Louvain</a>\xe2\x80\x94and generated a wave of refugees of over a million people. Over half the German regiments in Belgium were involved in major incidents.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHorneKramer2001ch_1\xe2\x80\x932,_esp._p._76_328-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHorneKramer2001ch_1\xe2\x80\x932,_esp._p._76-328">&#91;320&#93;</a></sup> Thousands of workers were shipped to Germany to work in factories. British propaganda dramatising the <a href="/wiki/Rape_of_Belgium" title="Rape of Belgium">Rape of Belgium</a> attracted much attention in the United States, while Berlin said it was both lawful and necessary because of the threat of franc-tireurs like those in France in 1870.<sup id="cite_ref-329" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-329">&#91;321&#93;</a></sup> The British and French magnified the reports and disseminated them at home and in the United States, where they played a major role in dissolving support for Germany.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHorneKramer2001ch_5\xe2\x80\x938_330-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHorneKramer2001ch_5\xe2\x80\x938-330">&#91;322&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKeegan199882\xe2\x80\x9383_331-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKeegan199882\xe2\x80\x9383-331">&#91;323&#93;</a></sup>\n</p>\n<h2><span id="Soldiers.27_experiences"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="Soldiers\'_experiences">Soldiers\' experiences</span></h2>\n<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/List_of_last_surviving_World_War_I_veterans_by_country" class="mw-redirect" title="List of last surviving World War I veterans by country">List of last surviving World War I veterans by country</a>, <a href="/wiki/World_War_I_casualties" title="World War I casualties">World War I casualties</a>, <a href="/wiki/Commonwealth_War_Graves_Commission" title="Commonwealth War Graves Commission">Commonwealth War Graves Commission</a>, and <a href="/wiki/American_Battle_Monuments_Commission" title="American Battle Monuments Commission">American Battle Monuments Commission</a></div>\n<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:BVRC-Great-War-Contingent_1914.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/b/b2/BVRC-Great-War-Contingent_1914.jpg/220px-BVRC-Great-War-Contingent_1914.jpg" width="220" height="95" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/b/b2/BVRC-Great-War-Contingent_1914.jpg/330px-BVRC-Great-War-Contingent_1914.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/b/b2/BVRC-Great-War-Contingent_1914.jpg/440px-BVRC-Great-War-Contingent_1914.jpg 2x" data-file-width="800" data-file-height="347" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:BVRC-Great-War-Contingent_1914.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The First Contingent of the <a href="/wiki/Bermuda_Volunteer_Rifle_Corps" title="Bermuda Volunteer Rifle Corps">Bermuda Volunteer Rifle Corps</a> to the <a href="/wiki/Royal_Lincolnshire_Regiment" title="Royal Lincolnshire Regiment">1 Lincolns</a>, training in Bermuda for the Western Front, winter 1914\xe2\x80\x931915. The two BVRC contingents suffered 75% casualties.</div></div></div>\n<p>The British soldiers of the war were initially volunteers but increasingly were <a href="/wiki/Conscription" title="Conscription">conscripted</a> into service. Surviving veterans, returning home, often found they could discuss their experiences only amongst themselves. Grouping together, they formed "veterans\' associations" or "Legions". A small number of personal accounts of American veterans have been collected by the <a href="/wiki/Library_of_Congress" title="Library of Congress">Library of Congress</a> <a href="/wiki/Veterans_History_Project" title="Veterans History Project">Veterans History Project</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-332" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-332">&#91;324&#93;</a></sup>\n</p>\n<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Prisoners_of_war">Prisoners of war</span></h3>\n<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/World_War_I_prisoners_of_war_in_Germany" title="World War I prisoners of war in Germany">World War I prisoners of war in Germany</a></div>\n<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:German_prisoners_in_a_French_prison_camp._French_Pictorial_Service.,_1917_-_1919_-_NARA_-_533724.tif" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f8/German_prisoners_in_a_French_prison_camp._French_Pictorial_Service.%2C_1917_-_1919_-_NARA_-_533724.tif/lossy-page1-220px-German_prisoners_in_a_French_prison_camp._French_Pictorial_Service.%2C_1917_-_1919_-_NARA_-_533724.tif.jpg" width="220" height="162" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f8/German_prisoners_in_a_French_prison_camp._French_Pictorial_Service.%2C_1917_-_1919_-_NARA_-_533724.tif/lossy-page1-330px-German_prisoners_in_a_French_prison_camp._French_Pictorial_Service.%2C_1917_-_1919_-_NARA_-_533724.tif.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f8/German_prisoners_in_a_French_prison_camp._French_Pictorial_Service.%2C_1917_-_1919_-_NARA_-_533724.tif/lossy-page1-440px-German_prisoners_in_a_French_prison_camp._French_Pictorial_Service.%2C_1917_-_1919_-_NARA_-_533724.tif.jpg 2x" data-file-width="3000" data-file-height="2205" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a
