It joined the war on the side of the Central Powers on 29 October 1914.</span>\n</li>\n<li id="cite_note-4"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-4">^</a></b></span> <span (1920\xe2\x80\x9346)">Hungary</a> was considered one of the successor states to Austria-Hungary.</span>\n</li>\n<li id="cite_note-8"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-8">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Although the <a href="/wiki/Treaty_of_S%C3%A8vres" title="Treaty of S\xc3\xa8vres">Treaty of S\xc3\xa8vres</a> was intended to end the war between the Allied Powers and the Ottoman Empire, the Allied Powers and the <a href="/wiki/Republic_of_Turkey" class="mw-redirect" title="Republic of Turkey">Republic of Turkey</a>, the successor state of the Ottoman Empire, agreed to the Treaty of Lausanne.</span>\n</li>\n<li id="cite_note-415"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-415">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">World War I officially ended when Germany paid off the final amount of reparations imposed on it by the Allies.<sup id="cite_ref-411" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-411">&#91;403&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-412" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-412">&#91;404&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-413" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-413">&#91;405&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-414" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-414">&#91;406&#93;</a></sup></span>\n</li>\n</ol></div>\n<h2><span class="mw-headline" href="#cite_ref-Tucker_2005_273_12-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-Tucker_2005_273_12-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text"><a href="#CITEREFTuckerRoberts2005">Tucker &amp; Roberts 2005</a>, p.&#160;273</span>\n</li>\n<li id="cite_note-crb.org-13"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-crb.org_13-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-crb.org_13-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-crb.org_13-2"><sup><i><b>c</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-crb.org_13-3"><sup><i><b>d</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-crb.org_13-4"><sup><i><b>e</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-crb.org_13-5"><sup><i><b>f</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-crb.org_13-6"><sup><i><b>g</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-crb.org_13-7"><sup><i><b>h</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-crb.org_13-8"><sup><i><b>i</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-crb.org_13-9"><sup><i><b>j</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-crb.org_13-10"><sup><i><b>k</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-crb.org_13-11"><sup><i><b>l</b></i></sup></a> <a Retrieved <span class="nowrap">7 December</span> 2013</span>. <q>...&#160;the assassination was followed by officially encouraged anti-Serb riots in Sarajevo&#160;...</q></cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=Reports+Service%3A+Southeast+Europe+series&amp;rft.pages=44&amp;rft.pub=American+Universities+Field+Staff.&amp;rft.date=1964&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fbooks.google.com%2Fbooks%3Fid%3DQGtWAAAAMAAJ&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AWorld+War+I" class="Z3988"></span><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r861714446"/></span>\n</li>\n<li id="cite_note-Kr\xc3\xb6ll2008-62"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-Kr\xc3\xb6ll2008_62-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><cite class="citation book">Kr\xc3\xb6ll, Herbert (28 February 2008). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=uJRnAAAAMAAJ"><i>Austrian-Greek encounters over the centuries: history, diplomacy, politics, arts, economics</i></a>. Studienverlag. p.&#160;55. <a href="/wiki/International_Standard_Book_Number" title="International Standard Book Number">ISBN</a>&#160;<a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-3-7065-4526-6" title="Special:BookSources/978-3-7065-4526-6">978-3-7065-4526-6</a><span class="reference-accessdate">. p.&#160;380.</span>\n</li>\n<li id="cite_note-FOOTNOTEHull2006307\xe2\x80\x9310-221"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHull2006307\xe2\x80\x9310_221-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a href="#CITEREFHull2006">Hull 2006</a>, pp.&#160;307\xe2\x80\x9310.</span>\n</li>\n<li id="cite_note-FOOTNOTEStevenson2004383-222"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-FOOTNOTEStevenson2004383_222-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a href="#CITEREFStevenson2004">Stevenson 2004</a>, p.&#160;383.</span>\n</li>\n<li id="cite_note-FOOTNOTEPainter201225-223"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-FOOTNOTEPainter201225_223-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a href="#CITEREFPainter2012">Painter 2012</a>, p.&#160;25. Over the course of the war the United States supplied more than 80&#160;percent of Allied oil requirements, and after US entry into the war, the United States helped provide and protect tankers transporting oil to Europe. US oil resources meant that insufficient energy supplies did not hamper the Allies, as they did the Central Powers.</span>\n</li>\n<li id="cite_note-FOOTNOTEStevenson2004385-224"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-FOOTNOTEStevenson2004385_224-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a href="#CITEREFStevenson2004">Stevenson 2004</a>, p.&#160;385.</span>\n</li>\n<li id="cite_note-FOOTNOTEStevenson2004Chapter_17-225"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-FOOTNOTEStevenson2004Chapter_17_225-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a href="#CITEREFStevenson2004">Stevenson 2004</a>, Chapter 17.</span>\n</li>\n<li id="cite_note-indiana.edu-1918-226"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-indiana.edu-1918_226-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-indiana.edu-1918_226-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text"><cite class="citation web"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.indiana.edu/~league/1918.htm">"1918 Timeline"</a>. <i>League of Nations Photo Archive</i><span class="reference-accessdate">. Retrieved <span class="nowrap">20 November</span> 2009</span>.</cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.jtitle=League+of+Nations+Photo+Archive&amp;rft.atitle=1918+Timeline&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.indiana.edu%2F~league%2F1918.htm&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AWorld+War+I" class="Z3988"></span><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r861714446"/></span>\n</li>\n<li id="cite_note-227"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-227">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><cite class="citation journal">Andrea Di Michele (2014). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.agiati.it/UploadDocs/12255_Art_20_di_michele.pdf">"Trento, Bolzano E Innsbruck: L\'occupazione Militare Italiana Del Tirolo (1918\xe2\x80\x931920)"</a> &#91;Trento, Bolzano and Innsbruck: The Italian Military Occupation of Tyrol (1918\xe2\x80\x931920)&#93; <span class="cs1-format">(PDF)</span>. <i>Trento e Trieste. Percorsi Degli Italiani d\'Austria Dal \'48 All\'annessione</i> (in Italian): 436\xe2\x80\x93437. <q>La forza numerica del contingente italiano vari\xc3\xb2 con il passare dei mesi e al suo culmine raggiunse i 20\xe2\x80\x9322.000 uomini. [The numerical strength of the Italian contingent varied with the passing of months and at its peak reached 20\xe2\x80\x9322,000 men.]</q></cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Trento+e+Trieste.+Percorsi+Degli+Italiani+d%27Austria+Dal+%2748+All%27annessione&amp;rft.atitle=Trento%2C+Bolzano+E+Innsbruck%3A+L%27occupazione+Militare+Italiana+Del+Tirolo+%281918%E2%80%931920%29&amp;rft.pages=436-437&amp;rft.date=2014&amp;rft.au=Andrea+Di+Michele&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.agiati.it%2FUploadDocs%2F12255_Art_20_di_michele.pdf&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AWorld+War+I" class="Z3988"></span><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r861714446"/> \xe2\x86\x90 see <a rel="nofollow" class="external free" href="http://www.agiati.it/ara_context.jsp?ID_LINK=113344&amp;area=196">http://www.agiati.it/ara_context.jsp?ID_LINK=113344&amp;area=196</a> for metadata --&gt;</span>\n</li>\n<li id="cite_note-228"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-228">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><cite class="citation web"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20070827142334/http://www.compiegne.fr/decouvrir/clairierearmistice.asp">"Clairi\xc3\xa8re de l\'Armistice"</a> (in French). Ville de <a href="/wiki/Compi%C3%A8gne" title="Compi\xc3\xa8gne">Compi\xc3\xa8gne</a>. href="http://digitalcollections.library.ubc.ca/cdm/landingpage/collection/WWIphoto">World War I British press photograph collection</a> \xe2\x80\x93 A sampling of images distributed by the British government during the war to diplomats overseas, from the UBC Library Digital Collections</li>\n<li><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://memory.loc.gov/diglib/vhp/search?query=&amp;field=all&amp;war=worldwari">Personal accounts of American World War I veterans</a>, Veterans History Project, Library of Congress.</li>\n<li><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://wikimapia.org/#z=10&amp;tag=1147"><i>World War I</i></a> category at <a href="/wiki/Wikimapia"
